reviewText:
I first played the original PC version of FF7, and then later the PlayStation version.

After purchasing and replaying the Steam version, I can wholly recommend it as the definitive version of Final Fantasy VII to play. I'll start off with some quick points about this version in comparison to previous versions. The actual game will be discussed in more detail below.

Vs Playstation:
+Smoother look on the characters
+No disc swapping
+English translation has been tidied up and the plot is more coherent (No one seems to talk about this, but it's major in my eyes)
-Swearwords have been replaced with !@#$ style characters.

Vs original PC release:
+Hassle-free, in my experience (40+ hours) <-- This is the key thing for me.
+PSX music added, as opposed to the awful original PC music. Huge plus! The song One Winged Angel" now has vocals like it should do :)
+Rendered characters are now synced perfectly when walking over a pre-rendered video.
+Videos look smoother and match the PSX version
date: which is very nice in comparison to original release.\n-Default keyboard controls need two hands. Original PC release had default keys all on the Numpad. Meaning you can scratch your chin or drink coffee while playing. Easily resolved anyway :)\n-Yet another thing you have to create an account for. This time for Square Enix. Once you've done so

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is a classic, there's no debating that. With it's first release on the Playstation back in 1997, this release is a repackaged version of the PC port released in 1998.  With cloud saves and achievements, it doesn't really stand out to people who may have already bought the game or have it elsewhere.

Final Fantasy VII uses almost all the assets from the original PC version of the game. Music was re-encoded to OGG Vorbis, but was still based off of fairly ugly MIDI tracks that the PC used. Thankfully they are easy to replace as some poeple have even decided to use remixes of said tracks instead.

Visually the game is very dated. 2D backgrounds, 3D sprites from that era with resolution stretching 2D elements while providing a modicum amount of improvement to the 3D models. While in the field, higher resolutions don't really help, but in battle scenes and in full 3D environments (Chocobo Racing, Submarine Minigame), there is a noticeable improvement.

Controls are a bit awkward as for a 360 controller, the triggers, d-pad, and right stick aren't usable. However, you can get around that either by binding everything to usable controls or using a utility like JoytoKey.

This is a bare-bones re-release, with the hard work for making it work with a modern OS stripped away for most people.

Update: SquareEnix has managed to replace the MIDI quality music with PSX quality tracks. This means the game's music sounds extremely detailed compared to the original PC release.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Final Fantasy 7
Original Release: 1998 (2013 Steam Version)
Genre Tags: JRPG; Turn-Based RPG; Action; Classic; Industry Jewel
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 20-65 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Nostalgia chasers; Strong narrative advocates; Gaming industry aficionado
REVIEWIf you scroll down the (serious) positive reviews for this game, you no doubt see many people expressing their nostalgic love for this legendary piece of their childhood. I stand among these people. For many of us who were kids in the 90s, Final Fantasy 7 was and always will be the first truly epic game we ever played. So I’ll admit that I am definitely biased to love it, as it was my personal favorite game during a number of years of my childhood. But that isn’t why I’m going to recommend that you consider trying it. You should consider it because Final Fantasy 7 is a classic piece of video-game history that revolutionized the genre and because it’s a kickass game.

At the time it first released, there were a handful of other large RPGs with huge worlds and a lot of gameplay (relative to the era), but they were uncommon and unpopular in the Western world. Final Fantasy 7 reached a pinnacle of awesomeness for RPGs that was unprecedented and subsequently elevated the genre into the mainstream gaming market outside of Japan. Not only did it have sound RPG fundamentals, but the sheer amount of variety of gameplay it offered was quite revolutionary for the genre. Chocobo racing and breeding, the motorbike scene, the snowboard scene, the Golden Saucer, the Don Corneo segment, and more all contributed to shattering the status quo for the genre. A lot of young gamers went from not knowing about RPGs to one of them being their favorite game ever. Not only that, but it became one of the cornerstones which provided a foundation for the genre to grow towards what it has become today. If there was a Video Game Hall of Fame, Final Fantasy 7 would no doubt be in it.

Obviously, with more recent RPG blockbusters from franchises like The Elder Scrolls, The Witcher, and Fallout, it is hard to continue to consider Final Fantasy 7 to be an “epic” game by today’s standards. Somehow it still feels that way to me. Or at the very least: since I enjoy the genre, I still find it quite fun to play.

So I will admit that it definitely has been a long time since Final Fantasy 7 was one of the best games in existence. That said, even after the erosion of the sands of time, the game still feels exciting, intriguing, and massive to me. Even on my 8th playthrough I pick up on new subtleties in the story or discover new secrets and items.

The story is interesting, if not a bit convoluted. (Some of the story was cut away to make it “less confusing for the Western market” or some such silliness. This wound up making it more confusing.) The Materia system is fun and, combined with the traditional XP leveling, continuously offers the satisfaction of progress as you play through the campaign. The world is intriguing and still semi-large(ish) even by modern standards. The characters are perfect clichés of the very clichés that they themselves introduced. And one of the best parts of the game will always be the intimidating boss battles with the signature music. It is doubtful there will ever be another kid who says Final Fantasy 7 is his favorite game ever, but most modern fans of the genre will enjoy this game despite its age.

So there are a few reasons you may want to consider trying this game if you never have.

If you consider yourself a true aficionado of the gaming industry, you will probably want to play Final Fantasy 7 at least once in your life. Even though there is a “remake” on the way (or out by the time you read this), I would argue you should play this version at least once to really experience a legendary piece of video game history in this semi-unadulterated state.

Or: if you don’t care about any of the historical mumbo-jumbo, and just are looking for a fun, turn-based JRPG, then you can comfortably look to Final Fantasy 7 for that as well.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T156pjmUxlE&list=UURLmXiAxqgzAGPO64W78sSg

Based on it's simple ultra low poly chibi characters and it's low resolution, pre-rendered backdrops, younger gamers would have a hard time believing that Final Fantasy VII was a cutting edge title in 1997. In addition to being a technical marvel in it's day, along side Resident Evil, Metal Gear Solid, Super Mario 64 and Ocarina of Time, it was an important ambassador for the potential of 3d graphics in gaming. Squaresoft had been working for some time to make their characters more emotive in order to sell their grand fantasy stories. With it's pre rendered cut scenes and fresh diesel punk and cyber punk informed sci-fi setting it allowed JRPGs to explode in popularity in the west.

Boasting one of the most thrilling openings in RPG history, players take control of Cloud Strife as he joins the terrorist group AVALANCH in order to destroy a Mako reactor. Cloud's former employer, an evil corporation named Shinra, is using these reactors to harvest a new form of energy that is destroying the planet and each of AVALANCH's members has a personal reason to fight against Shinra except for Cloud. Annoyingly enough, Cloud starts off as an angsty, aloof ♥♥♥♥♥♥ but slowly opens up, dealing with his own bag of issues over the course of the game. The rest of the cast is colorful and generally likeable. During the fight against Shinra a new threat emerges, shaking the plot up and introducing players to one of the most iconic villains in history. It's a narrative that is compelling though it seems a bit more silly now than it did upon release. Square has desperately tried to recapture the magic of Final Fantasy VII and often it feels like they have only managed to parody their own classic game. Final Fantasy VII established several character archetypes that are regularly found in many modern Final Fantasy titles and they have never been as likable as they were in VII.

What hasn't been cheapened by the failures of subsequent Final Fantasy titles is the combat mechanics. While the turn based structure may feel slow by modern standards, the materia system remains a phenomenally flexible system that effects everything from what weapons you want to use to your character's stats. Materia are magic crystals that are a byproduct of the mako reactors in the game world and allow characters to use magic. Each materia falls into one of several catagories: spell, command, support and summon materia. Each weapon and piece of armor has a number of slots to place materia in and some slots are linked allowing support skills to compliment offensive materia. For instance a poison materia linked to an added effect materia on a weapon allows characters to poison enemies or deal elemental damage. Final attack materia combined with life materia will instantly revive characters when they fall in combat giving yo a second chance during tough encounters. Characters don't really have classes, statistically some are better suited for certain roles than others but the right equipment allows any character to function in a desired role.

Personally, what has burned Final Fantasy VII into the deepest part of my memory for the past 17 years has been the soundtrack. From it's delicate melodies to it's whimsical themes, the soundtrack to this RPG classic is every bit as ambitious and epic as the rest of it's design. Since characters relay their dialog in text, the soundtrack serves as their voice. Hearing a character's theme several years after playing the game is like hearing the voice of an old friend. There is more humor, love, suspense and wonder in this game's sound scape than many entire franchises.

Final Fantasy VII is a classic and it's certainy worth revisiting for even experiencing for the first time. Thanks to a recent re-release on steam as well as versions available on the PlayStation network that's pretty easy to do. Unfortunately the port for steam isn't exactly exemplary. The controller support requires a mod to function properly, there are a handful of bugs and it requires registering with Square Enix. On the upside, there is cloud save support and achievements. In any case, I'd buy a lackluster port of a bonna fide classic if it convinces Square Enix to take a break from releasing embarrassing new entries into their flagship franchise in order to give gamers new and old a properly remade version of what is, arguably, the most popular game in their company's history.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII was one of the first RPGs I played, and the first game I bought for the Playstation. I had never seen anything like it at the time. Such a big, immersive experience. Three discs long! It was the first time I had seen a game span multiple discs. There's a lot to cover, so let's get started.

Breakdown of the game itself:

Graphics - The graphics in FF7 are very much a mixed bag. The 3D models used in battle are about as detailed as you could achieve for 1997, at least for console gaming. The models used outside of battle, however, are very blocky and much smaller. They sort of look like squashed down versions. It may take some getting used to if you're coming from a game like FF8, for example. FF7 uses pre-rendered backgrounds, which looked far superior to the 3D textures of the time and look great on standard def TVs, but look a little pixellated on higher res computer monitors. The FMVs still hold up pretty well, even if they're nothing mind blowing like they were for some of us back in the day. Personally, I think the spell/attack animations hold up the best out of everything, graphics-wise. I love seeing the animation for spells such as Aqualung. :)

Music - FF7 has some of the best music ever put into a video game, if you ask me. Nobuo Uematsu is a fantastic composer, and this game simply wouldn't be anywhere near as charming and compelling without his score, which does an incredible job of setting the mood for much of the game. Many of the tracks will tug at your heartstrings during the game's more emotional scenes, and many other tracks... Well, they just sound plain cool. The boss battle theme really got me pumped the first time I heard it, and I used to look forward to upcoming boss fights just so I could hear that music again.

Battle mechanics - FF7 uses an active time turn based battle system. You can have three characters in your active party, and each can equip a weapon, armor and accessory. Each weapon and armor has slots in it, which you can place little orbs in called materia. Materia are where you get your special abilities. Without them, you only have the standard attack and item commands during battle. Materia come in five varieties: Green, which contain magic spells. Blue, which alter the effects of a materia it is placed next to, if those two slots are linked. Red, which contain summons. Yellow, which enable extra battle commands (Steal, for example). And purple, which are basically stat boosting materia. These categories of materia are referred to as magic (green), support (blue), summon (red), command (yellow) and independent (purple). There is a TON of materia in the game and each weapon and armor can hold up to 8 materia orbs, so character customization possibilities are practically limitless. The materia system is honestly one of my favourites of any Final Fantasy or RPG.

Plot - You are Cloud, a former soldier of the Shinra corporation, which is basically the biggest world power in Final Fantasy VII. After parting ways with them, Cloud embarks on a new life as a mercenary, ironically being hired by a militant anti-Shinra group known as Avalanche. As you progress through the game you'll learn more about Cloud and his comrades' pasts and the various secrets the Shinra corporation holds, as well as the mako energy that's become so profitable for them. Along the way you'll meet lots of interesting characters, and there are even two optional ones you can recruit. I think that's a pretty good outline without venturing into spoilery territory. The characters in this game really have a lot of depth, for the most part, which is one of my favourite aspects of the game.

Controls - FF7 was originally released for the Playstation, but didn't make use of the analog sticks. It used the D-pad to move your character around, so you should be able to configure it to work with just about any USB gamepad you happen to have. You can also use your keyboard if you don't have a gamepad or simply prefer not to use one.

Issues specific to the Steam release:

First off, if you get an error when launching the game, try going into your program files (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\FINAL FANTASY VII\ for example) and right-click on FF7_Launcher.exe. Select Properties" and go into the Compatibility tab. Here
date: tick the box that says "Run this program as an administrator." This fixed the issue for me on my Windows 7 machine.\n\nThe only other issues I've had running the game have been it crashing a few times. Once when I first played through it on my laptop in 2013
recommended: just outside of the Mythril Mines (after travelling through them)
hoursPlayed: and a couple times when casting Beta on my current playthrough. Not ideal
voteText: but nothing to really worry about. Just make sure you save often and always after a major accomplishment.\n\nSo

reviewText:
Bought this for the Nostalga trip I was looking forward to. and I would love to recommend the game, except for a few quite significant things:

* Online activation of the Single-Player, Offline game before it will work. This relies on SE's servers working, which they didn't at the time of this review.

* You MUST have or create a Square account before it will launch. This is *Mandatory*, so yet another set of credentials that will need to be created and remembered. Haven't gone through that process yet because of outages. - No clear warning on the STEAM page for this game.

* From a brand new install, the ff7_en.exe file gets picked up by AV applications like Comodo apparently as malware, even though it's clean. This is apparently a known issue, and has been since July 2013 at least - There is NO warning about this on the STEAM purchase page.

How the hell can you butcher something so badly? I haven't even managed to launch the thing successfully yet due to these issues, which is why I have a stunning 0.2 hrs on record for the game, attempting to launch, get to the auth part, then then AV eating the .exe .. I shouldn't have to make an exception in AV settings for a game.

This is a SINGLE PLAYER GAME, and I was mistaken in thinking the Cloud saves and such were STEAM based - They are NOT.

Maybe I'll come back to it and try again another time. Right now, it's uninstall and added to the I regret this purchase" pile. My mistake for not researching deep enough before buying.

Thanks for butchering the memories Square.

Edit - They have finally put in that it requires a Square Enix Account in italics at the very bottom of the system requirements."

reviewText:
Final Fantasy is back. Again. For the 3rd time. But what's nice is this game is fully optimized to play on new hardware. I won't go into specifics on what Final Fantasy VII is all about, since unless you have been living under a rock, you already know. But for those rock dwellers, I will give some basics. Final Fantasy VII is an epic turn based RPG. One of the finest in its genre. It has a grand story. Memorable characters. An amazing soundtrack. Everything has aged wonderfully, except I'd say the visuals. Luckily with the power of the MOD, you can relive this classic with a fresh spin of the visuals (just search around) giving you a new experience on this gem. The only problem with modding FFVII is that you will need to roll back the exe which will in turn disable any achievements. So I'd suggest for achievement hunters that you play through the game unmodded. And replay it later with the beautiful mods added.

With that said, aside from better new system support, this re-release of FFVII also adds a higher res for the included character designs, as well as cloud saving, and a mode which will increase HP and Gil, with a seemingly tedious process. The latter mode is completely optional, but works in a way which does not hamper any enemy level scaling. It only boosts HP/MP, and not any stats or levels. So you will get the same scaling flow you would when playing it normally. This however does mess with your limit meter. So use at your own risk.


either way, FFVII is a great classic. Fans of it originally should check out this re-release. And newcomers need to experience this at least once in their lives.

reviewText:
I think after spending 200+ hours on this game, it's time to write a review.
You guys ok with this? If not, so sorry (sarcasm)

The PC version of FFVII! A great game gets a great PC port with a little graphic upscale on the side.

Pros:
This game is magic. Absolute gold. (And I don't even like FF games.)
Fun to play (I literally spent 200+ hours on this. I think I might be a bit biased)
Minigames.
Chocobos are fun to ride around on.
It will literally keep you busy for hours.
Controls well. (Although, I did not use a controller and I'm not sure if controllers can be used. I prefer keyboards anyway.)
Music is sweet.

Cons:
Master Tonberry (Stab stab)
Ruby Weapon
Emerald Weapon
Random Encounters

Analysis:
Upon first glance of Final Fantasy VII, I almost blew it off. Steam Christmas sales changed my mind quickly.
I picked it up and started it. The beginning was slow. Not slow enough to deter me from the glory that I would experience later on though.
You start off as Cloud, an edgy, roided up, Ex-SOLDIER mercenary. You are hired by AVALANCHE to rig one of the mako reactors to explode. You do this. Easy stuff.
Story continues (I'm not going to spoil anything. Just look at this review and determine if you want to buy it.)

You will find enemies that you will absolutely hate. I'm quite sure my least favorites were the parasites and Master Tonberry. The story will tug a few heartstrings. I choked up a bit when a couple things happened. There'll be some twists and turns that you might not expect (Unless you were played the original. Then enjoy this masterpiece again, friend.)
There'll be some goofs and gaffs. The characters are unique and their dialogue is entertaining.

DON'T TOUCH THE RED THING IN THE DESERT.
Still not going to spoil anything... but when you get to the ending, Be prepared to have some of your soul ripped out of you because it's so gosh darn good.

Conclusion:
The game is almost perfect. It's flaws will and have been pointed out, but I'm not here for that. I like the game for what it is and I highly recommend buying it. It's been worth the 200+ hours and I definitely got my money's worth.

reviewText:
I came into this game without any nostalgia at all connected to it, and came out thinking it was a masterpiece. A lot of people will say it hasn't aged well, and I agree to a certain extent, but it's pretty easy to get past the parts that feels clunky and outdated. If anything, it just makes the game feel more charming. The world is cool and interesting, the gameplay is fun (allthough sometimes it can feel just a little bit tedious) and the story is absolutely fantastic.

The writing focuses a lot on the characters, which I think is a great thing, personally. All the playable characters got a lot of attention and character building, which made me really care about them in the end, adding to the emotional roller coaster that is this game.

There are some pretty deep themes in FINAL FANTASY VII, such as loss and identity, and life and death. This only adds to the world and story, and makes it a much more unique and interesting experience.

It's a pretty dark and complex story, at least for the time it was concieved. It does however come off as a bit much at times, like a ridiculous scene in the early stages of the game, where the main character, Cloud, rides out of a large office building on a motorcycle, all while fending off enemy pursuers with a sword.

Despite this and a few other scenes, the story is very interesting and keeps you invested until the very end.

As someone who had never played this before a few weeks ago, I can see how this game became such an instant classic. I honestly consider this to be the best game i've ever played, and I want to recommend it to anyone, as long as you have the patience for the outdated gameplay and graphics.

reviewText: Final Fantasy VII is one of my favorite games of all time.  I had the original PC version back in the day and it ran flawlessly if I remember correctly. Makes no sense at all, but hey.  Still, it is an annoyance.  Once I finally got the game fired up, I immediately started having problems with my gamepad.  The cursor was flying all over the place.  I had to download a profile for Pinnacle to fix that and the fact that a few of the buttons would not respond at all.  Again, an annoyance.  Despite this effort my character still wants to walk to the left much of the time.  This I cannot seem to fix.  Sure, I can just plow forward and try to ignore it, but it still detracts from the game.  Lots of people have complained about the music or the fact that the graphics look terrible on current HD monitors.  That really does not bother me at all.  The same great gameplay is there if you can get to it.  The horrible controls completely wreck it.\n\nA person much wiser than me, who also owns this updated" version
date: told me that it was a better idea to just use a psx emulator to run this game if you really want to enjoy it again.  He was right.  Square totally dropped the ball on this one.  They have pretty much dumped all over the game that literally put them on the map.  I am definitely NOT saying that Final Fantasy VII is not a great game.  It is.  This is just not the version you want to play if you want to enjoy it."

reviewText:
A classic from the Playstation 1 era. This is one of the first RPG games I ever played and has always set the standard of what I expect from an RPG. It features turn based, but active combat, a fun and more-or-less easy to follow story, and decent characters and personalities though some border on the cliche. Finaly Fantasy 7 has a good amount of side quests and minigames that can eat up plenty of time. From snowboarding to breeding and racing chocobos the handful of side quests and metagames can keep you entertained for quite a while.

I found that, as with almost all RPGs I play, one of my favorite things to do is collect all the strongest magics and weapons. There are monsters you can encounter that are even stronger than the last boss at the end of the main story. On top of that there are magic abilities that, if you have the patience to level them up, can make the final boss a walk in the park. Getting these weapons and magics require a great deal of grinding though, which is someting I find to be rather offputting. Squeezing every last ounce of gameplay from this title will probably take you somewhere in the neighborhood of 70 hours if youre the occational gamer like me.

Since it's initial release the game has not really aged well. If youre looking for a top-notch Final Fantsy expierience I would point you to one of the newer titles. It's kind of hard to look at the old graphics in high resolution. To help this they have an original graphics" mode for people like me. It keeps the display to 480x640
date: but without the inherit funnyness of a SDtv set you still see plenty of jaggies and protruding polygons. The graphics didnt stop me from playing through one of my old favorites though.\n\nAnother gripe I have about the age is the clunky controls when roaming about but it's nothing you cant get used to. The button layout can be a tad confusing on the keyboard. If you happen to have a gamepad it eases this considerably
recommended: but you're probably going to have to spend a moment remapping the default controls-- no biggie.\n\nOne of my favorite aspects about the steam version is the cloud saving. True: its usless if you dont have an internet connection where you want to play. But I like the ability to play on my PC
hoursPlayed: go wherever

I have not used the feature mainly because I forgot my square-enix login stuff moments after i made it.\n\nIts not particularly weak in any areas but isnt as deep in character skill devlopment as I would like sometimes. Rather than molding your character(s) into what you want them to be

reviewText:
This game isn't just a game... It's the best story I've ever played. I'm 27 now, and have been playing this game since the day it came out. What tells me this is a good game... I can describe to you where I was when I played it. The time of day, who had the controller, my brother or myself.

If you haven't played this before, I welcome you to YOUTUBE some of the FF7 Remake Live Reactions. These videos hardly display the feeling a lot of people have for this game. Some of the most vidid memories of my life revolve around this game. I can't hear the word Cloud without picturing golden spiky hair.

*----------------SPOILER ALERT---------------------*

I remember the morning I sat and watched my brother play through the Forgotten City (Capital). The music plays in my head on a daily basis... I'll never forget the pit I had in my stomache all day after watching one of my favorite game characters die in Cloud's arms.

The story never stops unraveling, and has generated such a vibtant world I enjoy as much every time, as the first time.

Sure, games these days offer a lot of what FF7 had. But this is the game that really re-defined a whole Genre.

This (to me) was the end of Final Fantasy's Golden age. FF4, FF5 (Ish to me), FF6 and FF7. Incredible story telling, fun characters, memorable moments. 8 Was the start of a slide that they almost came out of with 10, but in my oponion...this is the best Single Player Final Fantasy ever made.

DYING for the new release. Already bought my PS4 for the occasion.


CONCLUSION: Unless you're not into fun games, awesome stories, crude language, and a fun guessing game of what they will have to tone down for PS4, BUY THIS MUTHA' ♥♥♥♥IN GAME!

reviewText:

- Opening bombing mission

- Biggs, Wedge, and Jessie's events

- Gold Saucer's minigames and date scenes
- Chocobo breeding
- Snowboarding
- Gaea's Cliff climbing
- Nibelheim flashbacks
- Tifa slapping contest
- Cloud's revelation
- Knights of the Round
- Omnislashing shirtless Sephiroth
and others not listed due to spoilers.

Things I still remember in FFXIII after 5 years:
- That Shiva bike?

It is easy to see why FFVII is a masterpiece in the series.

reviewText:
While Final Fantasy VII is a great (if very dated) game at its core, this has every symptom of a poor console port.  It's just a repack of the original port from over a decade ago.  Some things that show it's an effortless port:

-Characters faces are bugged.  All eyes are open, even if they're sleeping. All mouths are gaping, which looks ridiculous after a time.

-Controller mapping is awful (XBOX 360 controller).  The D-pad can't be mapped, which makes battle menus a pain.  You'll often accidentally slide to the side and choose Defend when trying to scroll down the menu.  R2/L2 can't be mapped.  The OK button decides to go turbo mode" frequently and skip dialog.

-No 16:9 mode (I don't count 4:3 awfully stretched to 16:9)

-Lots of odd crashes.  If you tab out of fullscreen

reviewText:
Fantastic game. It's a big adventure, you'll meet lots of different characters, good and bad guys. You come across so many different and unique places. There are lots of minigames, optional quests, and enemies to fight. The Materia system is really nice. It's fun to let Materia grow and allows for a lot of diversity in battle. Graphics are outdated, however, they give you that 90's feel. The soundtrack is gorgeous as expected from Nobuo Uematsu's fantastic work. People feel nostalgic for this game, and with good reason. It's a game every self-proclaimed JRPG fan should have experienced, especially with the remake coming up.

If you want to relive your childhood, or maybe experience a Final Fantasy game (or a Japanese RPG at all), then this is a good game to grab.

Some technical stuff: It has DRM, it requires you to make a Square Enix-account (not that hard), and it does have achievements and cloud saving. It can be played with a controller, I recommend using this fix, or using the Steam Controller and making a layout yourself. This version has smoothed-out graphics which make it look a little bit smoother than the original PlayStation-version.

reviewText:
You play as Clod, an intrepid hairstylist and transsexual activist, who engages in your typical SJW scare campaigns with his trusty band of internet activists, AVALANCHE. They kill tons of innocent people in capitalist Midgar, all in the name of social justice and some hippy ♥♥♥♥ about the planet. In your travels, you'll become Captain Save-a-Ho for a brunette table dancer in the slums, role play a smokin' hot ladyboy for a disgusting, rich dude, and murder thousands of innocent civilians just because Mr. T had a hunch. I have to admit, the characters in this game are horrible people, but their transformation into worse and worse human beings just might touch you the same way I touch myself.

JENOVA, the only redeemable character in the entire ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game and a hot monster girl with a body like wow, understandably becomes entirely too fed up with the human race and decides to end it once and for all. She manipulates Clod and friends to unseal a hidden magic, known as Black Metal, while she goads them into bringing said magic straight to her, utilizing her boytoy, Sephiroth, as bait (women, am I right folks?). Clod, realizing how badly he done goofed, selfishly takes a spiritual vacation while pretending to be handicapped for a stripper's affection. In this dark and twisted turn of events, the party must now stop the approach of a meteor in order to continue their selfish political campaign against Shin-Ra and the GOP.

This, the first and (as far as I know) last, installment in the Final Fantasy series will provoke a lot of emotions; those emotions mainly being disgust, confusion, and paranoia. It will make you lose faith in humanity and fall in love with planetary parasite aliens (both things I'm already all too familiar with). It will make you question your morals, your values, and most importantly, your place in this world -- plot holes, as big as the holes in my heart, will plague the internet for decades to come.

All in all, Final Fantasy VII is a experience, from beginning to end. The only thing I have against this game is the lack of choice in joining JENOVA to sterilize the planet.

Don't try to master Underwater Materia, it's a waste of time.

reviewText:
Boy, oh boy. How I usually avoid writing these kind of things.

So you know, whether or not this 'review' has a thumbs down is completely irrelevant.
I have a fond place in my memories for this game and it will always sit there, regardless of this ports overall quality.
It's by far and wide not my favourite of the series, but it sits high on the list.

That said, this is a passable port at best. At it's worst it's an OLD port of the original PC release.
The music, while seemingly a huge issue for some didn't even register with me.
The needless always online DRM for a game I've been playing since 1998 is also not a selling point, but once you've signed up for an account, it just becomes a minor hurdle to get into your game (not wholly unlike the Steam service itself). It's more a mark of the times in which we live than an actual mark against the game.

At face value, all of what made Final Fantasy VII such a fan favourite is still very much present in this port.
But recently sitting down to an in-depth playthrough (My first actual playthrough since buying the game on Steam) has brought some... Light issues to my attention.

- Graphics:
No, no. This isn't a Man
date: why do all the characters look like Popeye?" kind of graphical issue
recommended: this is more of a "Why update the models but not their faces?" issue.\nAs mentioned the models are updated
hoursPlayed: looking smoother with less pixelation on the edges
voteText: the characters really stand out against the background (sometimes they even stand out against the foreground for no reason) and it runs beautifully smooth
helpfulPercent: rarely any sign of frame lag. But as I said
votesHelpful: the faces for the characters seem to have been lifted straight from the Playstation version and then plastered onto the new models.\n\nBeyond that there are a couple of fascinating new gltiches/oversights that I've noticed. First of which being the gaped
votesTotal: open-mouth vacant look most characters seem to have. The most hilarious example being Sephiroth. Man
votesFunny:
is it hard to take Aeris' death seriously when Sephiroth is standing over her the whole time with his mouth wide open THE WHOLE TIME.

Obviously

reviewText:
An almost decent port sadly sabotaged with several problems making it impossible to recommend.

Its controller support is sadly lacking. With no way to assign the d-pad to up/down/left/right I'm forced to use the analog stick, which for this game (and its constant awkward movement angles) is seriously debilitating.

Cloud saving is apparently not working right now, which meant when I hit the first save point I actually couldn't save at all - even though it's telling me it's using local files, it just errors with a 'save file not found' first time I try to save.

It forces you to create a Square Enix account and 'log in' just to play the game - which is unnecessary and obnoxious, especially since the only benefit to the player, cloud saving, doesn't seem to be working, at least for me.

There are no graphical improvements here, so all in all I feel I'm better off running the original PSX version in an emulator than running this. Unless you really have a desire to collect achievements for some dumb reason...

reviewText:
What can you say about Final Fantasy VII that hasn't already been said?  It's one of the best Final Fantasy games to date, which is easily said due to all of it's spinoffs like the absolutely thrilling Dirge of Cerbeus, the wonderful prequil Chrisis Core, and the ever popular movie Advent Children (just to name a few).

That said, there are some good and bad with this Steam version of Final Fantasy VII, so lets get the list going;

CONS:

- Requires you to be online and sign in via Square Enix before playing.
- Cloud saving is slow (2-5 min pause) and you can't Save/Load until it's ready.
- No additional content added.
- Subtitles have been censored, which actually removes a bit of character emotion.

PROS:

- Final Fantasy VII
- Graphical Enhancements (allowing high resolutions).
- Video and Overlayed characters are better synced.
- Music has been updated (uses the higher-quality playstation audio tracks)
- Subtitles have been repaired" to remove "engrish" language.
- Fully mapable keys & controller support.
- Ability to disable cloud saving.

So is the game something I would recommend?  Of course it is!  It's Final Fantasy 7 for cryin out loud!  But...  If you already own a copy of Final Fantasy VII on a console than there is no real reason to get this one.  There isn't any new content
date: just updating for modern PC technology.  That said
recommended: if you have the older PC version (and love it) then replacing it with this one might be a good idea.\n\nAs far as the price
hoursPlayed: I don't actually believe this game is worth $17.  I'm willing to bet most individuals who are looking to purchase this game are doing so because they already have Final Fantasy VII and are simply looking to update it...  I purchased it during a 50% off sale for $8.49
voteText: which I consider a decent price.\n\nAll in all I'm giving this a NOT recommended.  Shocked?  Well it's true that I love Final Fantasy VII but Square Enix screwed up with a few things.  First
helpfulPercent: this is a single-player only game so an internet account should NOT be a requirement.  Second
votesHelpful: the regular price is a little high for a game that is almost 20 years old (no matter how good it is).  Third
votesTotal: the Cloud Save feature (which is the only real reason for being online) is so horribly slow you'd be better off going back to CD swapping.\n\nSo as much as I'd love to give this a thumbs up
votesFunny: because I really love this game
commentsCount: I simply can't."

reviewText:
Awesome game loved it since the day it came out on Playstation. The game isn't the problem here.

When I purchased and downloaded it there's a log in(yes LOG IN) screen I had to go through. You have to make a Square Enix account to play this game. Normally this is just an inconvenience. However, when I made my account the log in screen didn't accept it. That's right. The Square Enix log in screen for a Playstation game that came out nearly two decades ago did not accept my freshly made account.

After numerous attempts and password resets, it finally let me in. After playing for several hours and taking a break, I come back to find out the Cloud Saves did not process. HOURS of gameplay gone.

The Satanic login screen combined with the failing Cloud saves is enough for me to uninstall this game and just play it through an emulator, which looks just as good and works better.....with no LOGIN SCREEN!

reviewText:
Before you vote this review unhelpful solely due to the thumbs down, please read this: I recommend Final Fantasy VII! I highly recommend it. It's one of my favorite games of all-time. However, I do NOT recommend that anyone play this port! Please read on for details...

Final Fantasy VII is acclaimed as one of the high-water marks of the role-playing genre. Many gamers, particularly RPG fans, have played through this game not once but a multitude of times. I downloaded the new Steam version and played through it one more time on my PC to assess how the game has aged.

The very first thing that I noticed about the game was the chasm between how well the audio design and soundtrack have aged versus how poorly the graphics have. It becomes clearly apparent that sprites have aged far better than polygonal characters when comparing this game to an older, sprite-based games in the series such as Final Fantasy VI. Sprites carried a certain charm to them, and remain tolerable despite their lack of beauty. Polygons, for lack of a better description, just look strange and ugly. Their blockiness represents a human character far more poorly than even a sprite can. To compare it to Hollywood, sprites are like Disney cartoon of the '70s, while polygons are like the bad special effects of the '80s. The audio, however, has aged gracefully. Nobuo Uematsu's score has always been perfect for the game, and I remembered how fond I was of it the first time around immediately upon starting the game again.

Final Fantasy VII, to me, was the beginning of Square's hit-or-miss" character design specifically regarding western gamers. As a western gamer
date: I just can't see the appeal in a character like Cait Sith. While the majority of the characters still have good levels of depth and development
recommended: Cait Sith is a worthless entity who brings absolutely nothing to the game. He's a quirky stuffed toy injected into the game to please a culture that I just can't understand. Square Enix has continued down this path even further in future games
hoursPlayed: particularly in Final Fantasy XII
voteText: which saw two cherubic children as the main protagonists. Yuck. But there are some game-savers here. Cloud is such a deep and human character that it's worth playing through the game just to witness his growth. Sephiroth's villainy hasn't shown age
helpfulPercent: either. He's still one of the best gaming villains in history
votesHelpful: a title well earned.\n\nIt's obvious what to expect from the gameplay. This game is purely old school JRPG. It doesn't bother me
votesTotal: as it's a type of game that I once had a huge affinity for. I can jump back into the more slowly-paced
votesFunny: active turn-based battle systems any time and still enjoy it. To others
commentsCount: it may be a bit more tedious. This is especially true regarding random battles. As an old-school JRPG player
column16: random battles are familiar to me and sort of a necessary evil. To others
column17: the tedium may be intolerable. It's difficult for me to be objective enough to say.\n\nI've always loved the materia system. It's my favorite form of character development in any Final Fantasy game
column18: and it holds up. Growing your materia through the management of your weapons is so much fun
column19: and the high-level materia such as Slash-All and Double Cut really make you feel all-powerful toward the end portion of the game..\n\nThe main complaint that I have about the game is an issue that never seemed to bother me before. The control of Cloud through the various pre-rendered areas is absolutely atrocious. Pressing up on the directional pad will sometimes cause him to go left or right
column20: and pressing right or left on the pad will sometimes cause him to go down. There's no clear indication of when this will happen -- It's unique to each area. This becomes particularly annoying in areas where random battles occur. Very often I'd find myself doubling back due to this
column21: and fighting far more random battles than I actually had to.\n\nI wouldn't be able to conclude this without mentioning the cutscenes and minigames. The idea of rewarding players with a CGI cutscene during certain parts of the game was a fresh
column22: new concept at the time of the game's release. Seeing the devs at Square flaunt their graphical prowess was mind-blowing
column23: and the cutscenes were unlike anything in video games at the time. They truly were rewarding
column24: and I remember being so impressed as a 12-year old first playing this game that I recorded them on a VHS tape for later playback. The minigames were also groundbreaking
column25: but have aged poorly. Bad control plagues many of them
column26: specifically the motorcycle and snowboarding games. But the inclusion of these changed the genre for years; the lack of minigames in a post-Final Fantasy VII JRPG would be a strange omission for a later title.\n\nFinal Fantasy VII has got its problems. In some cases
column27: it's aged beautifully and become the historically powerful title that gamers expected it to be upon its release. Final Fantasy VII brought RPGs as a whole into the mainstream. Without Final Fantasy VII
column28: games like Mass Effect 2 and Fallout 3 may never have been developed at all. The graphics and control
column30:
will be nearly unbearable to any gamer going back in time to play this game for the first time.

As far as the Steam specific port that I'm reviewing here? Unfortunately... It's total trash

Every resolution that isn't 640x480 windowed looks terrible. They've upped the resolution on the characters and NPCs
column31: but the pre-rendered backgrounds are the same so they look awful in any other resolution. And don't even think about going to 16:9. All it does is stretch the picture to fit the screen. Barf.\n\nThere's also a persistent black bar along the bottom of the screen that is only ever filled in when accessing the menu. Imagine you're watching a film in letterbox
column32: except that there's only one black bar on the bottom of the screen and no matching bar on the top. Just awful.\n\nOn top of the graphical issues
column33: Square's ridiculous DRM is present. You must log into Square Enix when you first start the game. People already hate Uplay. Why would Square do this? It's an idiotic move.\n\nI'm a die-hard PC gamer
column34: but even I have to say that the best way to play this game in the modern day is to download the PSone port from the Playstation Store and play it on a PSP or a Vita. I wouldn't recommend the PC port to anybody that isn't looking to modify it heavily
column35: as mods are basically the only reason to purchase the PC rerelease.\n\nPeople have also mentioned the music quality being subpar compared to the PS1 version
column36: but it honestly didn't affects my experience at all. I've played through the game probably a dozen times since 1997 at this point
column37: and while I definitely noticed the music being different
column38: it didn't seem any worse than the original game.\n\nIn conclusion
column39: this game still remains a must-play for anyone who liked the original or any gamer looking for a history lesson. Like an old painting
column40: Final Fantasy VII continues to be historically relevant and is worth seeing and experiencing if only to recognize the influence it had on present day gaming. But the paint has aged
column41: and the artwork is unfortunately not quite as vibrant and stunning as it once was.\n\nJust don't play the newly released PC port. It's a bad."

reviewText:
Maybe it's just the time that I live in. The game's good and the music's cool and everything, but... Did people really care that much for these emotionless-looking blocks of people that consisted of two 3D polygons? Also the backgrounds are in really bad resolution and the game feels pretty slow... Especially in battles where there actually appears to be lag! Was this seriously  what the original game was like?!

Look, being faithful to the original release of a game is good. I love originals more than remakes most of the time! But there are some games that are better when they're remade, such as Pokemon HeartGold and SoulSilver. I think Final Fantasy 7 should have an HD version by now or something? I don't know, but this original PS1 version here just isn't drawing me in as much as I thought it would. It's NOT keeping my attention... Maybe I didn't give it enough of a chance? Still...

EDIT: ARG! How could I forget that whole... What do you call it? DRM? Why would you do that for a game that supports no multiplayer in anyway?! And don't give me an argument involving updates... That's Steam's deal, not yours Square Enix! People hated the Xbone for pulling the very stunt you're trying to pull on me now! I have half a mind to rush over to your site and delete my account because I don't want to ever support that!!

Not only that, but I hear bad rumors... Apparently the music I'm hearing is actually a low-quality version of the original? For real? Is this fixed or now? As a newbie I can't tell. But based on how you later treated FF8's Steam release... I'm starting to get the sense that I should never trust you, Square Enix.

I mean, I was dissatisfied with the game already when I thought I was playing the original game! Now that I am hearing these rumors and have been reminded of this DRM horror... Which I feel SUCKERED into...

What happened? Why are you doing this? I thought you were supposed to be one of the top game companies around! Don't tell me you're getting greedy and selfish too, like Microsoft is becoming and Capcom is (I hope) recovering from. It feels like these days I can only trust Nintendo and Valve to CARE for us...!

reviewText:
There is a reason many people consider this game to be one of the best games ever made is because of the gameplay and story. Final Fantasy VII starts the player off in Midgar, a city that uses the Planet's energy to use everyday tools such as electricity. A terrorist group called AVALANCHE plan on destroying the complany thats pretty much in charge of the world, Shinra Inc. Now what does this have to do with ur character? Well Cloud used to work for the company as a First Class SOLDIER but he eventually left and is now fighting with AVALANCHE to destroy Shinra. There is another plot in the story besides taking down Shinra which is killing Sephiroth. Im gonna let the players discover how big of a role almost every character is in this game no, series. Final Fantasy VII's story is so big and explained that there are 3 parts of it. Crisis Core is before the events of Final Fantasy VII and Advent Children which is a movie which takes place 2 years after Final Fantasy VII.
The presentation is simply amazing. Even though this game was first made on the Playstation 1 in 1997, the graphics still look amazing to this day. Almost everything is hand drawn such as the background but when ur enterting a train for example, the whole screen changes just to make the train move and than go back to the hand drawn background. The only reason y every character is almost entirely made out of polygons is because of the size of the game. For those who dont know, This game came with 3 discs on the PS1 so it makes sense for characters to be polygons.
The gameplay is awesome and theres 2 types of it. The first type of gaming is just roaming around in the world map and through villages/towns. The second type is the Role playing. You must wait till ur time gauge fills up in order to choose wat to attack. There are diffrent kinds of magic in this game and when you level up ur materia (items to improve ur characters) u may get increased damage as well as new spells such as using Cure3 when leveling up ur materia. You not only earn EXP but u also earn AP for materia. There are also Summons in the game like in almost every Final Fantasy game. Even though u ccant skip any cutscenes of summon cutscenes, its always nice to watch some animations such as Knights of the Round (Best Summon) and Bahamut ZERO's cutscenes.
I give this game a 10 out of 10 because even though this may not be acceptable graphics for this generation (2015). it still shows that u can break the limits of a PS1 by simply using more discs.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is an eternal classic from the PS1 era. Many gamers can tell you how iconic this gem from 1997 is. One piece of evidence showing that it is the most iconic JRPG game and one of the overall most iconic games of all time is its main character, Cloud, who many consider to be the most iconic JRPG character of all time (Cloud has the most playable appearances of any FF character of all time, including his addition to the latest Smash Bros game, and is the second most reoccuring character in FF games being beaten by Gilgamesh only - including non-FF games, Cloud may be the most reoccurring FF character of all time).

Its graphics were revolutionary (at the time), and its story is one that will live with most who have played it for the rest of their lives. Not only is the story immersive, but it also does something a lot of games fail to do, which is focus on all of its main characters. The game shows each character's growth and backstory in such a way that it is near impossible to not get emotionally invested in them. It even makes you feel particularly sorry for the bad guy, especially if you find some of the hidden secrets in the game that explain his story a bit more. It isn't the most popular Final Fantasy game of all time for nothing. The world in which FFVII takes place in has a wonderful futuristic and partially steam punk aesthetic, and its music score is one of, in my personal opinion, the best game soundtracks of all time.

If you have never played this game before, I highly recommend you do, because you are truly missing out on an all time classic.

One factor that everybody fails to mention in their review, is the fact that once you finaly register with Square Enix you can't log in to the game till you have link steam to your new profile on the Square Enix website. Once this is done you don't have to worry about the log in at the start of Final Fantasy VII ever again. For those that are queries, just follow these simple steps.;
1.) once you have finaly gotten your e-mail verify
2.) while logged in on Square Enix's website click on your account name in the top right corner
3.) choose User Settings
4.) click on Link Account
5.) click on the link button next to steam
6.) Follow directions from steam to allow the Link
7.) Enjoy Final Fantasy VII

reviewText: Final Fantasy VII is one of those games that everyone knows. It was revolutionary when it first came out for the PS1, and was one of the best selling games of 1997. The PC port is amazing. The original soundtrack was replaced with a newer soundtrack, and the graphics were also dramatically improved. I, personally, did not enjoy the music that was put into the PC port of this. However, with the aid of mods, I was able to replace the PC soundtrack with the classic PS1 soundtrack.  The PC port also offers 3 different graphics choices, depending on the preferences of the user. The user can choose between the PS1 graphics, or the PC graphics, as well as a mod that gives combat 3D graphics. One downside of this game, is the fact that you have to create a Square Enix account to play. This was a disappointment for me, but not enough to keep me from playing it. Aside from the technical aspects of this game, the gameplay is amazing. This is by far, the best game I have ever owned, because of the great story, the great soundtrack, the amazing combat, and the replayability. After spending over 500 hours on this game over three different game systems, I won't be stopping any time soon. I highly recommend FFVII, and honestly, this game is worth much more than $11.99.

reviewText:
I know the actual game-play of this game is good, because I own the game on the PlayStation. I bought this PC game to  support the future development of Final Fantasy games on the PC platform, however if this is the way Square Enix plans to treat the PC platform they just shouldn't support it at all.

I was aware of the DRM when buying. Having a single Square account seemed easy enough to handle and I was craving some nostalgia. So I created a Square account, but apparently it takes a while for the game to register an account creation because it didn't immediately register that my account was valid. I tried logging in on the opening screen for thirty minutes to no avail, but when I came back two hours later Square was finally ready to let me play my game. But when I started playing, I found myself in a fresh new nightmare.

The controls are atrocious with a keyboard. To keep things short, in order to interact with people, doors, and items in the game the character must be facing the object. The buttons are too sensitive and if I don't take my fingers off the movement keys at exactly the same time the character moves to face which ever key I take my finger off last, even if it's last by less than a millisecond, making the character turn in a direction the item is not in. It is infuriating to try to talk to people or open doors because of this sensitivity. I found my self trying many times just to interact with characters.

In order to not deal with this issue, I tried plugging in a controller- and the controller just as bad as the keyboard; the only way to move a character using a 360 controller is with the joy stick, the game IGNORES the directional pads altogether. It feels so wrong using the joystick in this game. Complaining about feeling may be nit-picky to some, but after spending so much time playing the original FFVII using the directional pad and playing all the other FF games using a directional pad, I have the question why Square willfully made this game ignore them. The PS3 and PSP versions of this game do not force players to use the joysticks, why do PC players, who normally enjoy the freedom of choice, get the short end of the stick with this game? I bought the game for nostalgia, and without good controls there is definitely no nostalgia.

At every turn, even from first booting it up, it seems Square Enix did not want me to play the game. So I have not played this game. I'll probably come back to it when I'm less infuriated, but ,if you buy it, do know this game comes with issues that Square Enix willfully put in the game.

reviewText:
I'm glad to see this game come to PC, since I don't own any consoles and I've heard my friends say for years how great of a game it was.  As a result, when it became available for a remarkably good price of four USD I picked it up.

That said, they could have done a much better job on porting this game.  By the numbers:

1.  The controls are permanently set, and if you don't own a gamepad you're permanently saddled with the most non-intuitive control scheme I've ever seen, where the binds make little to no sense and are scattered all over the keyboard.

2.  The client is inherently unstable, to a point where I suffered from 4(!) crashes by the time I had finished the first battle.  I'm talking complete crash to desktop restarts here.

3.  In addition to this glaring problem, the client hangs severely even when next to no load is being placed on the system.  The first fight, as mentioned earlier, while not overly complicated and only requiring a total of 4 attacks including the ones against the player character took me over five minutes to complete.  Now I know that I don't have the best computer in the world, especially when I'm playing on my laptop like I am, but this system has no difficulty handling modern games.  It should be taking FFVII and bending it over the table, but instead it hangs... especially in the CGI sequences where I had to use CTRL+ALT+DEL to force close the client a few times because the video had picked a spot and froze while the TERRIBLE 8 bit sounding music was on a 2 second loop that would make the most patient man in the world go insane.

To sum up, while I was very interested in playing this game, and I am sure that if it is patched to a playable state it will be excellent and enjoyable, I simply cannot recommend it to anyone in its current condition.  Ya let me down Square Enix.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII - The game that defined an era.

One of the greatest games, arguably on any console from any time. Final Fantasy VII is another epic installment from the Final Fantasy franchise, which needs no introduction. Released well over a decade ago, Final Fantasy VII still lives on in the memories of almost every RPG fan. Wether you played it when it was first released, or you are just trying it for the first time today, be prepared for a journey like no other. Join Cloud Strife, a seemingly selfish, arrogant mercenary as he fights at first for himself, but as the story progresses, maybe there is more to Cloud than you might think.

With an entire host of unforgettable characters, journey through a mass world, visiting huge cities, quiet coastal towns, beach resorts and much more, all backed with an incredible soundtrack by the legendary Nobuo Uematsu, this is a game that will not let you down, not the first time, not the tenth time. Final Fantasy VII truely is, one of a kind.

reviewText:
Chances are you already know what this game is and what most people think about it. If you're reading this to find out if the PC port is worth playing, then simply, yes it is. I heard people complain about the DRM and Square Enix account nonsense before buying it and all you have to do is make a Square Enix account through the game launcher one time and then it'll just auto log you in every time.

I heard people complain about the music problems, well thankfully they patched out the terrible midi music and put back in the original soundtrack that people remember from the PS1 so that's no longer an issue.

The graphics are improved from the playstation original, they've been upscaled and look noticeably better to where this is a preferrable version to the ps1 original. There's also no compatability issues like there was in the original pc port.

If you have never played this game before, buy it, it's one of if not the best JRPG of all time, and unlike later Final Fantasy games the story doesn't completely fall apart when you look through it critically.

reviewText: Final Fantasy VII is, in my opinion, the best of it's kind - crushing new games like Final Fantasy X easily. If you are capable to accept the simple graphics, you should really consider to play this game. In my opinion it has by far the best in-game and battle-system, giving the player the chance to find secrets and giving him the chance to obtain Bestias (powerful summonings which the heroes can summon at a certain state in the game) which are hidden somewhere in the game. Even though it's really old, it tried to do some easy render-sequences and if you want to the graphics are, with some know-how and troubleshooting, fully modable (be careful with spoilers while doing so). You should really try to play it some time, it served me well in 1997 aswell as now!

reviewText:
I first played this game when I was 12. I remember spending most nights either manically grinning at how cool the game and graphics were, or heartbroken by bit of storyline. I had the guide (lost in a move sadly), and its what made me turn from my megadrive to the pc for gaming.
Flash forward to 15 year later, when I see this for sale and think I will re-live the good old days. I have a family and work, so I'm still playing late at night, only difference is now I'm not being naughty up past my bed time. That being said there have been nights when my wife has walked in and I almost jumped out of my skin, thats how hard the nostalgia has hit me.
FFVII has some of the best characters, and is an amazing story. The only downside is the graphics which for a 19 year old game are pretty awesome, but thats not saying much by todays standards.
The remake is supposedly on its way, but I am wary about the innevitably changes and how it could taint my memories. That being said I will probably give it a go, but if you havent played the game, or like me you played it years ago I would recommend having another go now!

TLDR:
Re-live your childhood, or set it right with what you missed. This is easily my favourite game of all time. Just don't expect ground breaking graphics.

10/10 would be 12 again.

reviewText:
Do you really not know this game? Seriously, do I even have to write this? I want to note, that this was the first game I played when I upgraded from a Genesis to a PS1. I had never played an RPG before. This game introduced me to video games with true stories, even if the story is pure insanity. That said, instead of listing why it is awesome, I'm gonna tell you all the things that I know suck about it. Also note, I recommend it. I own it on PS1, PC hardcopy, and on Steam, so I want you to buy it.
1. The graphics. Holy ♥♥♥♥ are they awful. like seriously, so blocky and distracting and if I didn't love it so much I wouldn't even be able to play it and get past the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics.
2. Summons are so ♥♥♥♥ing long! They are beautiful, yes, even with ♥♥♥♥ graphics, but they get real tiresome after the 75th Knights of the Round.
3. As previously mentioned, the story makes zero sense. Yes, in broad strokes, there's supposed to be a pattern and such, but as you get to the details it is nonsensical. Yeah, the death scene was tragic and yeah I cried, ♥♥♥♥ you I was young and had no idea and had raised that character as one of my powerhouses, but despite that the rest is just crap. Also that death still seems to have no reason behind it.
4. Angst. so much angst! So much sad drama angst. Am I who I think I am? Are any of us truly human? Just... let me hit things with my giant phallic sword.

There's more, but I'll stop there. So yeah, buy the game. You'll still love it.

The Nostalgia is strong in this one.

reviewText:
Some people may find FINAL FANTASY series such a boring games,
but for me myself... i found this as a masterpiece.

FINAL FANTASY series is the best RPG games of all times
It's the games of my childhood, and I really have a big time fun enjoy
playing the FINAL FANTASY series, not only VII.
It's a 100/100 Metascore RPG game for me.


FINAL FANTASY VII :

Good Gameplay
Good Game Mechanics
Interesting Story
Excellent Music
Fun Mini Games
Interesting Quest
Some Secret Quest
Some Humors

The bad thing : the graphic is screw !! (compared to modern games today)
Yes ofcourse, coz it's a 1997 old classic game, was designed for PlayStation
and later on was released for Windows 95 / Windows ME.
And the graphic doesn't support widescreen.
Yes there is mod to fix this : Tifa Bootleg.


Ok about this FF VII Steam version :
----------------------------------------

FINAL FANTASY VII Steam Edition is just a new repack from an old classic 1997 Squaresoft game.


The Difference between the orginal and the Steam version is :

FF VII now become compatible with Windows 7

Worse audio file (dunno about today, but i heard SE later on just release the patch for this issue)

Need 1 new account at Square Enix. Well now customer got 1 more ID & Password to be remembered for a single player game (HEY THIS IS BAD !! It's FF VII single player offline not FF XIV)

New features : Achievement & Online Save & Character Booster

(Character Booster is the worst aspect of the game, it makes the game become not fun anymore, because our character now come with max hp and max gil..... You know what ? Our hero become too strong and the enemy become too weak now !!) Why don't SE replace the bonus with something make sense which not make our character become overpower ? such as : + 10 materia of medium level + some medicine (20 potion 20 elixir 20 ether) etc etc whatever.... instead of max hp and max gil :(


And i'm a bit dissappointed about the graphic option.
Don't get me wrong... i know it's a classic game, so i don't expect any high texture like modern - Geforce GTX 770 VGA - games today. What I mean is : If the game doesn't support widescreen, why do SE bother to give the widescreen resolution option ??? :D


So if u are a fan of high end graphic games -------> Don't buy this
If u already has FF VII and expect something new different in FF VII Steam Edition -------> Don't buy this


Well i just wonder, why SE don't remake this ? A full HD Remastered of an old classic best selling RPG game FF VII instead of just repackage it to be compatible with Windows 7 ?? :DD lolz


Ok let's check the FF VII forum......
I heard that they (the community of FF VII) has make a mod for FF VII (graphic texture, music, menu, etc...etc) much better than the company itself :D lolz hahaha


Shame on u LAZY SE :D   Many customers angry, and we maybe reconsider to buy the repacakage of FINAL FANTASY IX in the future. Why ??? Because u lazy !!! u lazy !! and liar !!  U don't make any worth improvement, u just repackage it and add new but not so worth features, and sell it with lies !! That's why many customers regret to buy FINAL FANTASY VIII (Yes FF 8) (repackage product of SE), even the old original 1998 PS version of FF VIII game has better music quality than the new repackage FF VIII of 2013 !! And some of them are vowed not to buy any future products of lazy liar developer, unless bla bla...... (well u know what i'm about to say)


I've been thinking of purchasing FINAL FANTASY VIII on Steam, but since that SE has broke this originally fantastic FF VIII (Graphic & Audio) to a disgrace level - a piece of crap, now i'm holding back !  I won't buy FINAL FANTASY VIII in this state for $ 11.99   :|

reviewText: FF7 is a game of split opinions. If you have never played it or any newer FF, you will love it. Lots to explore, fun side quests, some rather amusing scenarios you'll chuckle at, and a dark story to follow. The battle system is dated but very easy to learn but can be made interesting through 'sneaky' materia(magic) combinations. It is a fantasy world and sometimes things just seem to defy logic, just remember its japanese game things will be strange.\n\nIf you have played this game, then purchasing this version has nothing new for you unless you're N/A region. and even then its 2 optional bosses. everything else is the same. just looks nicer. doesn't play faster isn't harder, and some of the dialog appears changed.

reviewText: I never got the chance to play this originally on Playstation. It was always one of those games that I wanted to play, but could never find a copy of, so I was ecstatic when I found out that the PC port was available through Steam. One Steam sale and 36 hours later, I now finally understand both the hype and the hatred towards this game. Personally, I really enjoyed it and consider myself a part of the hype category. A colorful cast of characters that are well-designed and well-developed, a combat system intertwined with the Materia spell system for unique encounters and boss battles, and an amazing plot that kept me invested all the way through. Few JRPGs have held me for as long as this one has, rivaled only by the Kingdom Hearts franchise. There may be other entries in the Final Fantasy series that can be argued for over VII, but I can understand and respect why this game is held on such a prestigious pedestal.

reviewText:
It's Final Fantasy VII.  It looks terrible but is still one of the best JRPG experiences there is.  Very typical JRPG story, you and your rag tag team of people you met along the way are gonna take down a being of unmeasurable power and save the world.

There's cool summons that take to damn long to do what you want them to do, great cut scenes that make you forget how ugly the rest of the game is, cool weapons and characters to go along with great cities and locations.

If its a big long confusing story that makes you feel good when reach the end of it, then FF VII may be what you are looking for in a game.

reviewText:
A popular opinion among many, but FF7 is my favorite game of all time. Not just because of nostalgia, but because it is an incredible experience. While it has not aged well graphically, the story, soundtrack, and characters still stand tall. Fighting the Ruby and Emerald Weapons still has me mashing the O button hoping I don't get obliterated. The final fight between Cloud and Sephiroth still pumps me up as Cloud shreds him apart with Omnislash. The loss of arguably the most beloved character of all time still brings a tear to my eye. Hell, I will still attempt to bring Aerith back, knowing in the back of my head it's not possible, or I will try to get that mysterious chocobo the runs underwater or even outerspace knowing no such thing exists. Call me biased if you will but this game is a must play!

Infinity/100 greatest game ever!

reviewText:
It's Final Fantasy VII.  It looks terrible but is still one of the best JRPG experiences there is.  Very typical JRPG story, you and your rag tag team of people you met along the way are gonna take down a being of unmeasurable power and save the world.

There's cool summons that take to damn long to do what you want them to do, great cut scenes that make you forget how ugly the rest of the game is, cool weapons and characters to go along with great cities and locations.

If its a big long confusing story that makes you feel good when reach the end of it, then FF VII may be what you are looking for in a game.

reviewText:
Played this back on the ps1, one of my favorite Final Fantasy games.  Has a few bugs and some glitches, i cant remember where in the game, but they are easily bypassed.  Other than the few bugs, fantastic port, great game, brings back all the great memories from the original game on ps1.  This game also has a a massive amount of save blocks (unlock final fantasy 4) so you can save your game at all the cool parts in the game.

If you dont know the game, the story is detailed, the characters are awesome, and the game has tons of extras throughout the game.  The materia and limit break system takes a bit to get used to if you have never played this but its not difficult.  The game also has a feature to turn on max levels if you dont want to grind and work the trenches.  The game is not HD remastered, it is pretty much exactly the same port as the PS1 version, we are still waiting on that from squaresoft.  Considering this was made in 1997, its very impressive.

It is worth nothing that skill wise many of the characters are the same.  It is not like ff4 with a specific dragoon or ninja, or ff6 with a specific thief, or a specific martial artists.  The characters are differrent in look, have different weapons and limits, but they all have access to the same materia.  It would have been cool to have unique skills for each character to really set them apart not just from the story and visual, but in battle as well.

reviewText: Underneath the crusty PC port is the game I love, shining like a jewel. But, with cloudsaving that, more often that not, doesn't work, an immensely rocky entry because of an account requirement for a single-player  game that should not have been a concern even months after launch on Steam, and multiple progress stealing crashes, FF7 for PC is not a game I can recommend, even as a diehard fan. It is just too much hassle, both in and out of the game.\n\nUpdate: Not really as upset with the game, but I still don't recommend the game, even to my friends. People who love Final Fantasy will play this regardless, just as I have. I don't encounter nearly as many crashes as I used to because I play it on a stronger computer, but have still encountered some. Cloudsaving is still a consistent problem, however. Though it works more than it doesn't, the times it doesn't are frustrating and can go on for as long as an entire day. The irony in this is that the player requires an account or linking of Facebook info, in part, because of this feature. To force a player to go to such lengths just to play a game that never required this in the first place for a feature that works so infrequently is not a good justification. This is not even mentioning that Steam has these functions covered, should the effort be put in. In text, it seems like a poor port.

reviewText:
I'm torn, to be honest. Don't get me wrong, I LOVE Final Fantasy VII. The trouble is, I loved the original, back on the Playstation.

There really is no need for this game to have cloud saves, nor achievements, especially not for winning your first battle. Yes, the gameplay hasn't changed, and yes, I'm getting to play the game again. Hell, I bought the game three times, because I kept wearing out the discs from overuse. But a game that used a tiny memory stick to allow 15 saved games shouldn't need you to register online JUST TO FREAKING PLAY.

Yes I recommend playing Final Fantasy VII, but not this copy. Go grab yourself a physical copy and an emulator, it'll be better in the long run.

reviewText: I wouldn't call this port decent. It's stuck in an old 4:3 aspect ratio, and it doesn't even have mouse support. I can forgive it looking like pants because it was a PlayStation 1 game, and PlayStation 1 3d looked like your 5 year old gym underpants that you left in your locker and forgot about. Achievements and saves to the cloud do NOT make a good port, and, as much as I WANT to play this game for longer than 15 minutes, I just can't. It doesn't have mouse support, and its 360 pad support is dodgy at best. I also forgot the spinning before a battle. I don't usually have motion sickness, but that gives me a headache and makes me feel slightly nautious immediately. Buyer beware.

reviewText:
The visuals are great for the time, the soundtrack was and still is absolute dynamite, and it is rich full of culture (seriously, go read the actual wikipedia page on 'Sephiroth').

But bottom line, this game has not aged well at all. Majority of enemy encounters can be dispatched by holding down the O button.  You can't strategically use your Limit breaks in combat as you're forced to use them whenever they happen to pop up.  And 90% of the time, characters are all functionally identical besides melee or ranged".

Materia was criminally undercooked
date: there's not a lot to it. Something as simple as making Cloud levels materia faster
recommended: but will cause it to be weaker in the long run
hoursPlayed: would have helped.  Or some kind of mechanic where like: Tifa adds extra Agility stats to a materia as it levels up
voteText: so that can be swapped onto other characters to help out their stats.  Something to make me think about my party
helpfulPercent: how it's growing
votesHelpful: what lineup I'm running
votesTotal: and how often.\n\nIt's not always clear where I'm supposed to go
votesFunny: or what I'm supposed to do.  Seriously
