column16: or that I'm supposed to pick some (seemingly) unrelated text option for that guard to unlock the next zone.  Trial-and-error
column17: or just wondering around talking to everyone hoping they tell you something useful does not make for good game design.  I wont fault the story's execution as it was standard for the time
column18: but the endless text-dumps aren't helping.\n\nI don't hate this game
column19: and I'm not being deliberately provocative.  This game is just not nearly as amazing as people would have you believe
column20: it could have been so much more.  I acknowledge that this game is totally a part of history
column21: and deserves all the recognition for being groundbreaking (it was).  But this is not the greatest game ever made

column23: not by a longshot."

reviewText: Though I have not beaten the game on pc, I have beaten it and played it to its fullest hundreds of times on its original platform and to say the least: A complete Masterpiece. No other RPG you will ever play compares to this game. It was the first of its kind, when it came to visuals, story, and complexity. The materia and stat systems are created very well, and the game has around 50 hours of gameplay. This may not be a big deal today for an RPG but in 1997, the reaction to that was: Holy ♥♥♥♥. I cannot talk about the true nirvana that this game is and do it justice, so just please. Play it. It holds the top spot of my favorite video games of all time list, and most of all, has the top spot in my heart.

reviewText: Dear God... Do I have alot to say. First of all, this game has always looked like a fun and expansive RPG with many possibilities. It looked like an enthrawling adventure across a distant and obscure land. And I bet it is! But... Final Fantasy VII's prolougue just rubbed me the wrong way. I mean, first of all, the random encounter rate is atrocious,due to this and the battle system where an enemy can hit you while you choose an attack, I couldn't even beat the prolouge. AND THE FREAKING TIME LIMIT!!!!   I can't even put into words the absolute rage this time limit caused me. First - The Random Encounter Rate is FAR too high and that eats up about 6:00 of your 10:00 minute time period AND the game expects you to go speak to a random non-essential NPC in order to continue, this NPC isn't on the screen when you pass him! You have to remember where he was and just talk to him! LASTY atleast for the PC version, I was still getting my controls down during ths! I was slipping up, hitting buttons extra times and very simply screwing up. My apologies to diehard Final Fantasy fans across the world, but I just can't whole-heartedly recomned this game. Maybe if you can get past the prolouge without tearing off your toes and mailing them to Square Enix, this would be a great game.

reviewText:
I can recommend FFVII on steam, since in itself it is an awesome game, but don't expect SE to have done much to improve upon the experience.

Pros:
- Awesome game - one of my personal favourites.
Cons:
- No updated textures - In my opinion, the game is made for an old CRT monitor, and it shows.
- Requires SE account to play.
- I had a lot of trouble with cloud-saves not working.

I can recommend using a controller as well, since its much more natural and it helps bring back the old PS nostalgia.

reviewText:
After the many years of this game being out and playable in various platforms I have finally taken the time and played this game for the first time.

I see a lot of the praise this game gets for the Final Fantasy franchise for the creative and beautiful graphical achievements it did back in the day when the game was first released. It also had quite a deal of depth in the nature of option side-questing things that would give you good rewards for the effort (even though there were some I had not even tried/found.)

The musical score definitely had some wonderful pieces in there that definitely set the mood and the feels with the story. Speaking of story this is where I believe it faltered a little. There were some parts that I felt were not needed or were not explained thoroughly for what it was showing. Some parts felt even patched in just to add more to the story and extend the gameplay. If it kept to the main theme of what the game hummed all along the story would have been solid.

In the end though: I'd still give it a few more playthroughs just to see all the bits that I had missed for a first playthrough and try different team combos.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is basically the first game that I ever pre-ordered in my life when purchasing a game. This was when I was just a little kid, and was quite excited about the Japanese release of Final Fantasy VII. It took me months to beat this game on first try, and about 8 years ago, I bought myself an English version of it and beat it in 1 week. I still remember myself doing the final battle over and over, as it was very entertaining back then. And now Final Fantasy VII has got some HD treatment (Not sure I can call it a full HD....as it appears only the character models look decent and the background looks quite distorted still as the original. Meh, prob not a HD. Doesn't matter though) and what can I say. This game just never gets old. reviewText:
I first had this game on PS1 as a child and absolutely loved it. Fantastic story and great turn-based battle system, I had as much fun playing through it now than I did 17 years ago. For me this game truly is a classic and holds up very well.

100% Achievements 80-90 Hours
To 100% this I had to spend about 20 hours grinding for Materia Overlord (Master all Materias) and Master of Gil (99,999,999 Gil). If going for 100% and you want to do it in one play through I would recommend using guides because there are lots of places where a achievement can be missable.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is one of two games I have ever completed 100%.

Most of us feel nostalgic thinking about games we loved as kids. When I pick those games up again, I usually don't complete them and almost never feel the excitement and joy I felt when I was younger. I usually am bored within a couple hours at most, finding myself looking forward to putting down the controller.

Final Fantasy VII is different. I don't have the same nostalgia regarding this game that I do for some others, but this is a game I picked up planning to just plow through the story once again to see if it lived up to the great game I used to think it is. Well, I ended up getting sidetracked early on, exploring every little thing I could. I was grinding for limit breaks on characters I never had any intention to use. I still managed to be in awe at some cinematics despite their obvious age.

This game is about as impressive as games can be. If you're looking for a JRPG and haven't played this, I urge you to grab it and sit down with it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: It's FINAL FANTASY FRIGGIN SEVEN. What the hell else do you need to know? It's still one of the best JRPGs of all time, and the game that would come to define an entire genre for over 10 years. Ignore whatever preconceptions you might have had about this game being overrated, or any kind of bad taste left in your mouth from the mostly-terrible Compilation of Final Fantasy VII. This game really is as good as you've heard, from the tight and expansive battle system, the highly customizable characters, the massive world filled with nooks and crannies to explore, and, of course, a great story. In Final Fantasy VII, you play the role of Cloud, an ex-SOLDIER working with a resistance company called AVALANCHE to take down his former employers, the Shin-Ra corporation. Along the way, you'll encounter giant rideable chickens, swords the size of your house and then some, more existential crises than you can wave a giant unwieldy sword at, and, of course, a whole pile of homoeroticism. The PC port could be better, but it's still pretty decent. It doesn't really matter, because this is a game you NEED to play.

reviewText:
This game is definately one of the best RPGs EVER!
A game is so much more that state of the art visuals like you see nowadays.
Playing only a few minutes you can see that the music and the story create an atmosphere that sucks you in immedately. Together with an excellent sense of humor there is only one thing you can say about this game: Everything has been done right!
The music became a classic, seen tons of remakes. The character development finds hardly a game that matches this. Not in sense of simply leveling up, finding/upgrading items but in developing an personality. That fact I missed on FF 8 where the main caracter stays to cool and emotionless.
The game itself is from 1997 and I played it in the early 2000. And it still drags me into the story. I love to see it on sale again. But having a boxed version is priceless :P

reviewText: I don't know where to start, but FFVII is one of my fav game for years now. When I first met with the title Final Fantasy, it was on my PSX many years ago. Right now the visuals are outdated. Ofcourse they are, because the game is 16-17 years old (almost an adult). But still one of the best jrpg out there in my opinion. You could ask me, that why is it so good, I will tell it, but remember, these are only MY opinions, not facts. First, i loved the whole story, the flashbacks, backgrounds of the characters. Second, i rly loved almost every music in the game (Imo Cosmo Canyon Theme is the best). And the third, that i like the most and miss in many other games, these are the mini games. For me the most fun was the Chocobo racing and the Chocobo farm. And one more thing, if I'm correct, then FFVII was the Game of the year in 1997. And one little thing, if anyone saw the movie Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children, but never tried the game, then I highly recommend atleast 1 playthrough.

reviewText:
Final fantasy 7 is the best final fantasy ever created, and also one of the best games ever made, The story starts as the hero being a gun for hire, and as the corporations plan unfold, the heros loyalties and emotions shift, and something develops for him worth fighting for.
The storylines build up is fantastic and has you wanting more constantly throughout, Sephiroth as the heros rival, and the end games main enemy is one word BRILLIANT.
The battle system is your standard turn based, however what seperates this is the summons and the mastering of summons, magic, and other types of materia
Materia is the games main power/skill/magic system and tbh one of the best ideas I've seen next too final fantasy 3's job system.

Even if you've played this game as I have, another purchase of it and you wont be dissapoointed.

10/10

reviewText:
In my opinion; the game is a defining classic for the RPG genre.

My first experience of the Final Fantasy series was with this title back in 1997 and at the time it was absolutely incredible. This was different to any other game I had played, the story was rich and enthralling, the score and graphics were both bright and vibrant but also moody and atmospheric when the scene dictated it and there was so much FMV that it felt like you were playing an interactive movie. The variation in scenery, the number of side activities, the secrets and the challenges keep this game alive for days longer than the main story (which is fairly large in it's own right as it is).

Every Final Fantasy fan has their favourite and I'm not going to argue with anyone that doesn't agree; I have played and continue to play every one of the main series titles I can lay my hands on and although each of them has their charms I would still rate VII as my first choice.

reviewText:
Return to Midgar and defeat Shinra. A classic Final Fantasy that everyone loves and enjoys time and time again. Through the emotion, the sadness and the hardships. A game that should be experienced by all. If it really helps you to conclude the story play in this order:

Crisis Core (PSP)
Final Fantasy VII (PSX/PC)
Advent Children (DVD/BluRay)
Dirge of Cerberus (PS2)

And then the story will be finished. Probably the most overatted Final Fantasy in existance with that much just to explain the lore and mythology of Final Fantasy VII, but it's still good nonetheless. But I think why it get's so much praise, it's the first game that a lot of people played first and introduced them to the RPG genre. But I honestly don't praise it that much... But it's good in it's own right. But do take it from me; Play it!

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII has long been one of my all-time favorite games.  The updated Steam version corrects some of the problems that occured on modern Windows systems due to some rushed coding on the original PC version, but more importantly, it makes a formerly rare PC game available once again.

The plot of FF7 is very rich and detailed, but unfortunately poor translation and the rush to complete the game caused the story to be very confusing.  In many ways, the mystery of the plot adds to the game experience, while it does cause some frustration at the end.  Because of the rich storyline, I found it was worth many playthroughs over the years to look for the additional clues and hidden plot points that explain some of the details and where all the characters fit in.

And it's the characters that make the game interesting.  The primary cast of Cloud, Tifa, Barrett, Aeris, and Sephiroth remain some of gaming's most iconic and memorable characters.  And the supporting characters, major and minor, are also fascinating.  The guilt and dual-nature of Vincent Valentine, the relationship between Cid and Shera and his regret, Reeve's internal conflict, the stories of characters like Zack, Ifalna, and Lucrecia who reveal the origins of the crisis, are all interesting to explore and witness, along with the villians such as Rufus, Don Corneo, and of course, the truly despicable Hojo.  This is a story where people aren't always who you think they are, characters are in conflict with each other and themselves, and terrible losses occur on the way.  For gamers of my generation, there is a single scene I won't divulge here, but you'll know it when you see it, that sticks with you long after the game because of how strong the characters are.

As far as the game mechanics, it's pretty well done.  FF7 introduced the ATB timing system to Final Fantasy games, which combined real-time and turn-based mechanics very well.  Like other FF games, it's about a lot of stats, a lot of random fighting for experience and AP, and I lot of organizing equipment screens, but the systems in FF7 are not so intimidating or confusing as other games in the genre.  Many of the stats don't have a lot of importance in most situations, making fine-tuning the numbers less necessary so long as the characters are leveling enough and have decent gear.

What makes FF7 unique, even among FF games, is the materia system.  By arranging gems called materia, a character can gain magic and special abilities and change them as necessary between fights.  Unlike FF8's junction system which discouraged the use of magic, FF7's materia grows in strength when it is used and equipped.  The materia system is something I've always liked about the game.

In many ways, the game hasn't aged perfectly.  Mainly the graphics, and the wonderful soundtrack was originally presented in a midi format. This version updates the midi to OGG, but still isn't great.  Unfortunately, the excellent work by the Qhimm forums on restoring the PC version of this game to greatness is not compatible with the new release of the game, only the original and Platinum Hits versions.

Overall, this game is legendary, and essential for anyone who calls themselves a gamer.  If you play normally, expect 40 hours of gameplay, if you choose to explore and look at everything while combing for secrets, make that 60-80, and if you rush and use walkthroughs, you can do it in 20.

reviewText:
There's no doubt that this game is a classic, whether you like or not. But if it's actually held up all these years, that's a little more subjective.
Expect blocky character models and low resolution (but still quite good looking, IMO) static backgrounds, and all the spelling and grammar errors from the original PC release are still here. However, the music has been replaced, the original MIDI soundtrack is now the same music used in the Playstation release, and the game overall has been optimized to run on new systems. The actual game mechanics and combat system are solid, and the story is also still good.
If you've never played the game, don't come in expecting something that can stack up to a game released today in terms of graphical quality. If you can look past its age there's still a great game and plenty of time to be wasted in it, though. If you're looking for a nostalgia kick then it's definitely worth the price as well.
The only detractor from what's overall a good game is the extra layer of DRM, requiring a Square Enix account, but considering it can be activated with your Steam account and ignored once you set it up the first time, it's hardly a hassle.

Final Fantasy VII practically pioneered the 3D RPG (albeit, very oddly. Look at those polygons!), and paved the path for several other famous 3D RPGs as well. The Materia system makes for a unique, simple game mechanic that's easy to understand and use. Steam's $12 pricetag fits like a glove for this. If you're kind of iffy on RPGs but want to try one anyways; this is the game for you.

reviewText: If you haven't played Final Fantasy 7, then you probably don't like JRPGs anyways. That said, it's probably the quintessential posterchild for modern day JRPGs, and one of the games that helped bring them to the mainstream. Final Fantasy 7 is easily one of the better JRPGs ever made, but also one of the most overrated. Also keep in mind, this game requires you to be always online, for DRM purposes, but gives no real benefits to this requirement other than Achievements. If you are wanting to play a JRPG, and are unable to find an original disc of this game, then this is the best alternative.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: FF7 was the most groundbreaking RPG of its era. It was the edge that gave Sony dominance in the console market, the hammerblow to Nintendo's pride and the straw that broke Sega's back. It represents the pinnacle of Sqauresoft's history and in the eyes of many, no single player RPG has come close since. It also spawned one of the most recognisable bad guys in gaming history. The heavy anime style gives it a very Japanese feel, Nobuo's music is fantastic, from the energetic guitar based battle themes to the heartwrenchingly sorrowful Aerith's theme. A game that excited a generation, filling our heads with unforgettable memories of an awesome, immersive experience. It's a must play for any hardcore RPG fanatic.

reviewText:
Final fantasy 7 is the best final fantasy ever created, and also one of the best games ever made, The story starts as the hero being a gun for hire, and as the corporations plan unfold, the heros loyalties and emotions shift, and something develops for him worth fighting for.
The storylines build up is fantastic and has you wanting more constantly throughout, Sephiroth as the heros rival, and the end games main enemy is one word BRILLIANT.
The battle system is your standard turn based, however what seperates this is the summons and the mastering of summons, magic, and other types of materia
Materia is the games main power/skill/magic system and tbh one of the best ideas I've seen next too final fantasy 3's job system.

Even if you've played this game as I have, another purchase of it and you wont be dissapoointed.

10/10

reviewText: This is one masterpiece of RPG right here. It has great story, characters, music, and it's fun to make your own decisions to see how everything turns out. Unlike other RPGs this one has pretty fast paced battles, and implements mechanics that other RPGs don't, making this game unique. The default PC controls can be a little difficult to get used to, but are easy to use in most circumstances and you can change them any way you like. One feature I like is the Limit Break feature, because getting the crap beat out of you then taking your revenge with a Braver or Cross Slash Limit Break can be very satisfiying. I can't wait to get farther in the game, and I would personally recommend this game to any fan of RPGs or Final Fantasy. My Score: 9.7

reviewText:
In my opinion; the game is a defining classic for the RPG genre.

My first experience of the Final Fantasy series was with this title back in 1997 and at the time it was absolutely incredible. This was different to any other game I had played, the story was rich and enthralling, the score and graphics were both bright and vibrant but also moody and atmospheric when the scene dictated it and there was so much FMV that it felt like you were playing an interactive movie. The variation in scenery, the number of side activities, the secrets and the challenges keep this game alive for days longer than the main story (which is fairly large in it's own right as it is).

Every Final Fantasy fan has their favourite and I'm not going to argue with anyone that doesn't agree; I have played and continue to play every one of the main series titles I can lay my hands on and although each of them has their charms I would still rate VII as my first choice.

reviewText: I don't know where to start, but FFVII is one of my fav game for years now. When I first met with the title Final Fantasy, it was on my PSX many years ago. Right now the visuals are outdated. Ofcourse they are, because the game is 16-17 years old (almost an adult). But still one of the best jrpg out there in my opinion. You could ask me, that why is it so good, I will tell it, but remember, these are only MY opinions, not facts. First, i loved the whole story, the flashbacks, backgrounds of the characters. Second, i rly loved almost every music in the game (Imo Cosmo Canyon Theme is the best). And the third, that i like the most and miss in many other games, these are the mini games. For me the most fun was the Chocobo racing and the Chocobo farm. And one more thing, if I'm correct, then FFVII was the Game of the year in 1997. And one little thing, if anyone saw the movie Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children, but never tried the game, then I highly recommend atleast 1 playthrough.

reviewText:
This game is definately one of the best RPGs EVER!
A game is so much more that state of the art visuals like you see nowadays.
Playing only a few minutes you can see that the music and the story create an atmosphere that sucks you in immedately. Together with an excellent sense of humor there is only one thing you can say about this game: Everything has been done right!
The music became a classic, seen tons of remakes. The character development finds hardly a game that matches this. Not in sense of simply leveling up, finding/upgrading items but in developing an personality. That fact I missed on FF 8 where the main caracter stays to cool and emotionless.
The game itself is from 1997 and I played it in the early 2000. And it still drags me into the story. I love to see it on sale again. But having a boxed version is priceless :P

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is one of two games I have ever completed 100%.

Most of us feel nostalgic thinking about games we loved as kids. When I pick those games up again, I usually don't complete them and almost never feel the excitement and joy I felt when I was younger. I usually am bored within a couple hours at most, finding myself looking forward to putting down the controller.

Final Fantasy VII is different. I don't have the same nostalgia regarding this game that I do for some others, but this is a game I picked up planning to just plow through the story once again to see if it lived up to the great game I used to think it is. Well, I ended up getting sidetracked early on, exploring every little thing I could. I was grinding for limit breaks on characters I never had any intention to use. I still managed to be in awe at some cinematics despite their obvious age.

This game is about as impressive as games can be. If you're looking for a JRPG and haven't played this, I urge you to grab it and sit down with it.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is about a stuggling jack of all trades who, at one point, questions his sexual outlook. After spending some time living as a lady in the slums, he realises he isn't meant for such roots and decides to wage war on the local pimp who ♥♥♥♥♥s out woman as if they were objects.
Together, with the help of his female companions, they strike down the slumdog pimp and soon set their sites on bigger motions in works, Why stop the lesser evils when they can overthrow a government who oppress their people in order to gain monopoly for themselves?
Our hero, Cloud, then sets off, hesitantly, on his way to see change brought to the land and its people. Through trying times, he bonds well with those around him and gains invaluable strength and bravey through out.
Soon the group learn they are in way over their heads when they come across a talking dog, who's tail is constantly on fire (he doesn't seem to mind, though), and through the actions of said dog, they learn of a great evil at work. Sephiroth.
Sephiroth was once a mentor, an idol and symbol of hope to Cloud, and the world at large. However, after learning of dark secrets kept from him, Sephiroth seeks vegence on those who wronged him - the Goverment known as Shinra. He learns he is nothing more than a lab experiment and that his mother was an alien. Naturally, Sephiroth is all like hold the damn phone here

reviewText:
FF7, too many words to describe how awesome this game is - Lets begin.

1, In my lifetime i've bought this game 4 - 5 times now, this is because PS2 games were the easiest things to lose as a child for some reason, one was from the Square Enix store and their Cee-loud services but no key for steam and once again on steam because #Enix couldn't come up with steam keys.

2. The amout of mods available for this game to make it into HD is astonishing, 16GB but astonishing - I have yet to install these mods yet but once i do i shall be uploading videos or some ♥♥♥♥, i'm not entirely sure but enough about me and mods - the game right?

Final Fantasy has a way of destroying the ♥♥♥♥ out of your time, you play the game at 9AM and you get off at 8AM, its just one of those games that gets you instantly hooked, the storyline and plot is a bit iffy but once you're towards the end it will all make sense, sorta. If you've played any other Final Fantasy Game that isn't Vincents offspring or Crisis Core - You will know, this is a pretty original Final Fantasy.

Alot of people love the movie because of the game even if neither of them are any relevance to eachother besides the characters and summonings + Sephiroth Battle, speaking of Sephiroth battle - Let me make this crystal clear if i can - how can every boss you encounter me so mutated then you meet sephiroth and he's just stupidely mutated then at the very end {SPOILER} You hit a 0 and he dies, sweet, dramatic ending to a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ fight

Besides all that, alot of people have found exploits and random things about the game in which the average person wouldn't look for, this is always fun to explore on youtube or google. I do recommend this game because I've never personally bought the same game more than twice and usually thats for a friend so for me to have bought this for 4 - 5 in a row now - Pretty astonishing.

But i know you guys don't know me, this is a review for the game so ♥♥♥♥ you. :D
<3

UPDATE 17/06/15 - So i herd you like re-males, it would appear that this game is being remade.
on next gen, FF7; this beautiful game is going to make me cry at night now.

reviewText: I've loved Final Fantasy VII for years, I still have the discs for the fist play station. Am I ecstatic that they put it on steam??  Do you even have to ask???  For those of you that have never played any Final Fantasy games, I totally recommend that you try this one first.  The graphics are the same as they were on playstation if there are any of you that are like me and remember the game.  Steam also has a guide for all of those hiding potions,GFs, etc... and guides you through.  The only change that I've seen so far of couse are that you use the keyboard keys instead of the playstation controller.  The keyboard keys are not hard at all and pretty well lined up. I would recommend this game to anyone young or old, because   even back in it's newest days it had an awesome story line.  I have yet to see a game come even close to this game's story line.  The story line,and the fact that in many parts of the game you are free to go run around the map and level are  two of the best things about this lovely turn-based rpg.  There are many other good things about it but I'd rather not spoil anything for you.  Happy Gaming!  I know it'll be a happy gaming day for me for sure!

A classic.  Chances are if you're buying this you've played it already.  If not, well you'll get to see what all us thirty-somethings are talking about.

There are options to run at a higher resolution and dither the textures and stuff like that... but there isn't much point.  This game has polygons and fmv's and whatnot - but it's really born from a 16-bit era design philosophy.  Keep that in mind while playing - it's more about the story than the presentation - and that story is a parable for the true struggle of our age, which is why it resonates with so many people.

The irony here is that Squenix is behaving more and more like the evil corporation in its cautionary tale...

Worth the 40 or so hours, I say.  Get it.  Run it at low rez.  Punch Square-Enix in the face for big-brothering you before letting you play.  (An account is required!)  Wish you had just kept your Playstation and curse the death of privacy.

Square:  Either you die Squaresoft... or you live long enough to see yourself become Square-Enix...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Game: Final Fantasy VII
Genre: RPG
Publisher/Developer: Squareenix/Squaresoft
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 93/100
Value Score: 9.3/10

• Story: 10/10
• Characters: 10/10
• GamePlay: 8/10
• Graphics: 9/10
• Sound: 9/10
• Music: 10/10
• Length: 10/10
• Replay Value: 7/10
• Player Value: 10/10

Pros
+The Steam port's resolution is higher than the PS1 versions and also fixes the glitches and errors of the original PC version
+Ability to play in PS1 visual style or in Steam visual style (higher resolution)
+Music has been patched to the PS1 version's OST rather than using the original PC version's OST which was remixed and unpopular
+Achievements have been added
+A Character booster is available for anyone to use to increase their HP and MP to the maximum 9999/999. It also boosts the amount of money/gil.
+Cloud saves available not tied to the Steam server but Squareenix's online server
+Some of the issues that the PS1 version and original PC version have been fixed such as a Mdef bug and the way chocobos are moved during in Chocobo farm

Cons
-Black borders may appear if played in higher screen resolution however only during battles and in towns (there are no black borders in menu or world map)
-Control manual and tutorials have not been updated and use the keyboard's instructions regardless of whether using a controller or not
-Some sound effects may glitch out and keep on repeating or be cut off early (rare)
-Cutscenes are in low resolution/standard PS1 resolution
-FPS in battles are still 15 FPS, 30 FPS in world map/towns and 60 FPS in menu just like in the original PS1 version

reviewText:
Well well, what must I say about this game, voted as one of the greatest video games of all time, seen as one of the best games in the Final Fantasy franchise, and known for its colossal impact on gaming? Well. If your a gamer like me, who plays games by heart and not eyes (heart being story and eyes being blown away from games featuring explosions guns and violence), then this is a game for YOU. Before I go in depth of how amazing this game is, I must tell you how I got into the Final Fantasy franchise.


As a kid I shied away from the series because honestly the roman numerals in the games was just too confusing and at the time I was a strict Nintendo fanboy. Times have changed, I am no longer a strict Nintendo fanboy though I still am but now I accept other games. I gave Final Fantasy 1 a try and quickly got hooked. Then I moved on to 2 and at that point it was clear I am now a Final Fantasy fanboy. I then went to 3, and at the time (all of this happened recently btw), there was a Steam deal going on. The Square Enix publisher discount stuff. Final Fantasy 7 and 8 were in that, and I had some spare change and decided it would be a fantastic idea to purchase two Final Fantasy games with the highest amount of reputation within the franchise. I did not regret that decision, it was clearly worth buying. Now, back to our discussion on why the game is great.


This game, is addictive. No, not addictive in a bad way like Minecraft (You know, playing all day losing your mind). Addictive story-wise. The story in this game is ENGAGING ON SOO MANY LEVELS. IT DOES NOT AT ALL FEEL LIKE I AM PLAYING A GAME ITSELF, BUT WATCHING A MOVIE WITH A DEEP STORY AND AMAZING CUTSCENES AND FLASHBACKS. The gameplay itself is interesting and apealing to me. When I play the game, I don't care for the gameplay, I am anxious to see what happens next in the story. When a game gets you feeling like this, it is clear why Final Fantasy 7 is regarded or arguably one of the greatest games of all time. Its games like this one we just don't see anymore, it really does suck because I myself wish that these games with all these DLC's and micro-transactions would just STOP and use this game as an analogy to what a perfect game should be. This game is a classic, I had no problems with it other than how frustrating it was to get my freakin Square Enix account setup. If you can get past that one problem, you got yourself a perfect beautiful game right here. In conclusion, I say if you are one who enjoys a great story with fun gameplay, then this game is worth your 12 dollars. Or, at the moment if the deal is still going, its half off.

reviewText: The RPG genre was never really considered a mainstream or popular genre -- that is, until the release of Final Fantasy VII on PlayStation. With Final Fantasy VII's historic release on PlayStation in June of 1997, role-playing games were finally given the respect that they deserved and the RPG genre is now one of the most significant and defining on the system. Following the story of Cloud Strife, gamers were taking on a fantastical journey that encompassed three CDs and over 40 hours worth of gameplay. The game continued the trend of using the series' staple turn-based battle system, complete with melee and elaborate magic attacks.

reviewText:
With the upcoming remake of Final Fantasy VII there will definitely be mixed reviews about which is better. the remake or the original? The least any newcomer to the Final Fantasy franchise can do is to play the original first before any potential shortcomings the remake may have to offer.

For most the 1997 release was their first Final Fantasy and is therefore special to them. Upon replaying FFVII on Steam I had such an overwealming nostalgia which quite honestly surprised me. I could remember everything so clearly even after almost 20 years since first playing it. Everything was the same as I had imagined it even back then, though I will say that this updated version has a few things which had been changed. Certain dialogue and so on, though I don't think this is such a major issue to many.

The Materia system is still top notch, though now I am certainly more cautious with what I use instead of throwing everything on a character just because I had it, as I would have done on my first playthrough. Plenty of mini games to keep one entertained when sick of grinding or just want to take a break from the story. The battle system was exciting for its time, especially with the added Limit Breaks which were a huge improvement on VI's Desperation Attacks. which were quite frankly rubbish. The fact you could save the special attack for a better time as well as evolve them into better ones by using them was a reason to try out every character, just to see what they did. With the new release, the old battle system will certainly be dead and buried so we can probably say goodbye to many of the epic moves and abilities we once encountered.

The soundtrack? 11/10. Nuff said.

If anything, this is one of my least favourite Final Fantasies in the franchise, though it was my first. Even though I prefer most of the others, this truly is a special game that will not only challenge you, but become a part of you in the process. It can be a bit of an eyesore to look at in this day and age, but if you love a story rich game then there's nothing really stopping you from buying this game.

reviewText:
I'll make it simple.

The DRM has turned me off from what should have been a lovely trip down memory lane. What blows me away is that I cannot even play a single player game without either giving out my Facebook credentials or creating a Square Enix account. Games for Windows Live did not work and neither will this. Learn something Square.

Not only that, but the 'reset password' function on your website does not even work so I cannot recover an account that I apparently made with you. AND. I can't login using my Facebook unless I agree to let them post on my behalf. In my infrequently humble opinion, this is a mood killer. You know why? Because the only thing that let me play the game was allowing it to hijack my Facebook. Final Fantasy sucked after 10, you're not going to piggyback on my account just to talk about how great your recent 'products' are (if they could be called that). So needless to say, I revoked that permission and uninstalled.

I loved this game growing up and still love it and nothing breaks my heart more than to have spent money on it and to realize that I'm going to download a cracked copy anyways just to bypass this incredibly uneccessary and ridiculous DRM. Avoid this version of the game everyone. Unless you have a Square Enix account handy (hopefully you remember your password) or have no problem giving away all your details on Facebook to a company that believes you cannot be trusted with a re-release of a PC port of one of their most popular titles ever and arguably one of the most popular RPGs ever released on the planet, you're not missing out.

Dust off your PSX or PS2 and get an original copy. It will be less of a hassle than running it in this garbage version.

I can't describe how thoroughly disappointed I am in you Square.

reviewText:
I was seriously loving this game, up until the point where all of my saved game files were missing except for one I had towards the beginning of the game. My time played is a stretch, since I left the game on for some time, but I still had put in a decent amount of time goofing around, stealing ethers, learning monster skills, etc. So, now I've lost that progress, and I can either restart or quit. I've read up that this has something to do with cloud saving, but this game has been on steam long enough that it should have been fixed a LONG time ago. In my mind, this is the equivalent of if square had come into my childhood home, taken my ps1 memory card, doused it in gasoline and then flipped me the bird as they dropped the match. I'm sure I'll at some point grind my way back to where I was and use the work around, but if you don't want the headache, find another way to play this game.

+Great story
+Great old school RPG elements
+Awesome characters

-Takes all of those things and deletes them on a whim

reviewText: At first glance, this looks like something great to get. And I will admit, it looks and runs as smooth as you would expect from a computer version, but the game has ONE fatal flaw.\n\nIf you have to alt-enter out of the game, you CANNOT get back into the game or do ANYTHING on your PC. I'm using a windows 8.1 PC, and have had to hard reset my laptop because when I tried to alt-enter back into the game, the screen turns black. All functionality remains, but you cant see a thing on the desktop. You can open anything on the taskbar, or from the Start menu, but you cannot see it. You can't get FF7 to re display the graphics, and you cant get the screen to display anything but black. I dont know it I'm the only one who has experienced this issue, but this is a REAL game killer for me.

reviewText:
With the upcoming remake of Final Fantasy VII there will definitely be mixed reviews about which is better. the remake or the original? The least any newcomer to the Final Fantasy franchise can do is to play the original first before any potential shortcomings the remake may have to offer.

For most the 1997 release was their first Final Fantasy and is therefore special to them. Upon replaying FFVII on Steam I had such an overwealming nostalgia which quite honestly surprised me. I could remember everything so clearly even after almost 20 years since first playing it. Everything was the same as I had imagined it even back then, though I will say that this updated version has a few things which had been changed. Certain dialogue and so on, though I don't think this is such a major issue to many.

The Materia system is still top notch, though now I am certainly more cautious with what I use instead of throwing everything on a character just because I had it, as I would have done on my first playthrough. Plenty of mini games to keep one entertained when sick of grinding or just want to take a break from the story. The battle system was exciting for its time, especially with the added Limit Breaks which were a huge improvement on VI's Desperation Attacks. which were quite frankly rubbish. The fact you could save the special attack for a better time as well as evolve them into better ones by using them was a reason to try out every character, just to see what they did. With the new release, the old battle system will certainly be dead and buried so we can probably say goodbye to many of the epic moves and abilities we once encountered.

The soundtrack? 11/10. Nuff said.

If anything, this is one of my least favourite Final Fantasies in the franchise, though it was my first. Even though I prefer most of the others, this truly is a special game that will not only challenge you, but become a part of you in the process. It can be a bit of an eyesore to look at in this day and age, but if you love a story rich game then there's nothing really stopping you from buying this game.

reviewText: I've loved Final Fantasy VII for years, I still have the discs for the fist play station. Am I ecstatic that they put it on steam??  Do you even have to ask???  For those of you that have never played any Final Fantasy games, I totally recommend that you try this one first.  The graphics are the same as they were on playstation if there are any of you that are like me and remember the game.  Steam also has a guide for all of those hiding potions,GFs, etc... and guides you through.  The only change that I've seen so far of couse are that you use the keyboard keys instead of the playstation controller.  The keyboard keys are not hard at all and pretty well lined up. I would recommend this game to anyone young or old, because   even back in it's newest days it had an awesome story line.  I have yet to see a game come even close to this game's story line.  The story line,and the fact that in many parts of the game you are free to go run around the map and level are  two of the best things about this lovely turn-based rpg.  There are many other good things about it but I'd rather not spoil anything for you.  Happy Gaming!  I know it'll be a happy gaming day for me for sure!

reviewText: The RPG genre was never really considered a mainstream or popular genre -- that is, until the release of Final Fantasy VII on PlayStation. With Final Fantasy VII's historic release on PlayStation in June of 1997, role-playing games were finally given the respect that they deserved and the RPG genre is now one of the most significant and defining on the system. Following the story of Cloud Strife, gamers were taking on a fantastical journey that encompassed three CDs and over 40 hours worth of gameplay. The game continued the trend of using the series' staple turn-based battle system, complete with melee and elaborate magic attacks.

reviewText:
What could I ever write here that hasn't been said before. I remember putting in 70+ hours into this game when it first arrived to Playstation back in 1997. What I can say is that the PC port, while not the HD remake we always hoped for, provides a little more polish than it's 1997 counterpart and remains a distinct landmark in the Final Fantasy series.

Graphics & Story: For the era it was produced in, FF7 had compelling graphics along with full motion video and a great cast of unique and interesting characters. Famous scenes such as Sephiroth's walk through the flame engulfed Nibelheim or the fateful moment in the Forgotten Capital provide the gamer with the type of immersion that has tried to be replicated through numerous games following FF7's release.

Music: With Nobuo Uematsu at the helm, there was no doubt that the soundtrack would be any less than great. One-Winged Angel is one of the most memorable compositions in Video Game history and Aerith's theme provided the perfect emotional tone for that pivotal moment in the Forgotten Capital.

Again not much more I can say but that I can't wait for the HD remake - 10/10

Update: Mar 16, 2015
Finally finished my 100% achievement file. Hoping we hear something regarding a sequel or remake in 2017 on the game's 20th anniversary. Give Final Fantasy VII a try if you've never played it before. This classic is certainly worth the time.

Update: June 16, 2015
Well holy hell....the remake is happening.

reviewText:
As an avid FF player, I have to say that this is my favourite game in the series.

The turn based battle system is great. A complex and very intriguing storyline with likeable and relatable characters brings the story to life. You have endless sidequests to do that can take away the edge of grinding. If you are not a fan of grinding for exp and levels, then this game may not be for you. It has great replayability.

If you like RPGs and do not mind reading vast amounts of dialogue, then I highly reccommend checking this game out! If the news of the remake has brought you here, then give the original a chance! You will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
A timeless classic RPG that has been loved by many people since the original release.
I remember playing this game every few years never quite managing to fully complete it and now I begin again with the hope of an eventual completion that will make life worth living.

The game runs fine apart from the occasional crashes though it only tends to happen when the game is minimized and this is easily avoidable.

The steam achievements give an additional gameplay factor to help spurn on the dedicated player, though it would be nice to have a few more that are inventive and challenging rather than requiring a mass grind session (Of which we tend to do already) or perusing youtube/guide sites in order to find glitches and bugs to aid in the completion from almost twenty years of playing.

I would recommend this game to all generations, as a long time fan of the final fantasy series (Waning in recent years due to the class of game they have released). I will rack up the hours gladly and not be disappointed that my life accomplishments end here.

reviewText: Square Enix's PC re-release of Final Fantasy VII (FFVII) is a much welcomed surprise for old school gamers who have fond memories of the original PlayStation. reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is a special game, there basically none like it.Not for its history but there are not as much potential games being made like it, not enough games with its ambition or originality. It transcends all of what is expected and surpasses all basically. This game is not overrated or neutral in my book, in fact it is indeed considered underrated now for me, it’s been a while since people experience it’s raw power but it is still is to this day one of the best games ever made. . Of course the stands of its title as the best game ever made are still pretty known yet dismissed which is very sad because this is an overachiever of an experience ESPECIALLY compared with the rest of its series and many of the genres.  It’s faster than what its series is normally is; its gameplay is simpler and funnier, having personally one of the best mechanics ever, the materia. Especially considering this is one of the best games I’ve played I recommend it to anyone really. It’s just a nice smooth experience even if you aren’t the type to play big games to the end; I really recommend this, even I someone who cannot support this type of length it is still a game that every second manages to show me something cool. It is basically my saving grace on long JRPGs and perhaps video games in general. The gameplay is one of the most mechanically best I’ve seen, simple and straight to the point unlike many other games that take a long time to get to the basic of it, this one gives you it all at full front and doesn’t hesitate to make it entertaining at all times. Magic is simple to use by any character using the materia system which is the best system ever, they’re these little magic pearls that once equipped within your weapon can be used, they can also be combined with slots that are combined slots which you can make combos with such as (A “Cure” materia with an “All” materia makes it possible to use that magic on all). On top of this the materia can be leveled up as you battle to be more efficient by gaining , not only this, all characters within the game are extremely useful even without the power to equip any materia you wish from battle power to healing! Every character has a Limit Break which is when they get hit a couple of times and can’t take it anymore, they will release a power blow that is mostly based on their characteristic, for example Tifa Lockhart will use wrestling moves done by a roulette a system, and Aeris’s first limit will be to give some health to the 3 of your team.
The entire game’s backgrounds are made with these amazingly animated CGI pictures that are filled with detail and are always cool to look at, it has beaten any texture or tile pack in its genre of how memorable and incredible it’s visuals are. Not only that but a fair share of interactive cutscenes blending in with the game’s models, an insane amount of in-battle animations with over a thousand enemies with their unique attack patterns and styles and in general lots of effort put into to the limit.
I used to dislike this game due to my short attention span I grew to notice how much it has to offer especially compared to others of the genre; it has indeed a wider variation of options while remaining simple and straight to the point, from dialog, to character selection, to how many weapons and powers you can acquire, different styles to take on an enemy entirely there are various choices to do on side missions side too and you can collect rare items as you explore a giant world, collect more, experiment with powers, there are multiple statues that are negative and positive, a round of elemental powers given to about anything in the game including actual weapons you receive, accessories that facilitate you by nullifying certain types of times and just a huge number of other statistics that yes while describing seems complex but seems very natural and simple within the game, all this to discover new ways to make gameplay easier and this is all done in a balanced manner quickly.. It’s a bit long to go into detail about each content you can go to but as an example there’s a materia that allows you to turn enemies into items.
The plot is amazingly crafted and designed; it is filled with foreshadowing, flashbacks and not an adventure that manages to keep continuing without any breaks and always a bigger goal in front.  Out though yes everything within the game is almost as If a satire of how simple it is, mostly everything is based of clichés and yes it’s mostly comical and never 100% reassured (I mean c,mon by this point you would tell yourself “Oh I guess the magic goop heals all of the plot’s wounds” to be honest or “Must be symbolic” because really It’s a just science fantasy with a more serious turn), but that only comes within the standards of nitpicking, I mean honestly, if you were to go to the single first bone of this game realistically you would think to yourself “Isn’t ecoterrorism flawed?”, but don’t worry they later on in the game kind of regrets what he did to save the planet SO HEY Plot filling exists at a high level in this game, this game can truly sustain itself in terms of plot elements sometimes even if it’s silly so I’ll end it at that considering there’s many other silly major plot concentrations that can be easily taken away in a bad way if you don’t see it from the adventurous perspective or ATLEAST EXPLORE THEM!  What’s there is there, it’s a simple story within a typical cyberpunk sceneario and I’m more than ok with that, other than that the implied adult themes are strong… And the adult themes that are straight up shown are STRONG TOO! This game is still pretty grimdark to this day, it was the first of the series to introduce real issues such as poverty, world pollution, life goals, what death means to a person and how to live with it amongst other deep contents in which the game casually comments on with a quote or 2, perhaps even an entire character built on the topic. Some may complain on how it tries to deep but for me it’s more the merrier, it isn’t the best psychological take on characters but it certainly isn’t the worst, especially compared with what Japanese media takes as “Psychological” it could BE WAY worse.  Either way I appreciate it’s psychological tones it gives the plot way much depth and it doesn’t deliver itself at first glance, anyone against it must REALLY hate people with actual personalities that are basically perfect cardboard main characters, again it’s balanced because the characters themselves are competent, which is needlessly to say the necessary for a character, outside of that you can have your emotional problems as long as you use it to power yourself within your journey, I give this long speech about character development because IT SEEMS This HAS BEEN DONE WRONG MANY TIMES and Final Fantasy VII manages to do it alright. This is THE adventure, the most over achieving product in history, this game manages to hold my attention in all of the aspects it gives, a great and full of effort game that has grown out to be known as the best game ever made numerous times, it comes with a dark well designed plot filled with numerous great characters, it’s silly, humorous  and memorable,  it’s filled to the brim with content which is all amazingly crafted (which honestly is the reason why I fear this review might be TOO basic to cover up the entire game), there are 4 hour long documentaries which document every aspect, nook and cranny from this full of experience game. I mean it doesn’t seem much like it but I’m actually trying to refrain myself from writing more than a book here considering there is so much to comment on! This is my Final Fantasy. Also not full revie

reviewText:
I see little point in discussing this game's content because by now it's probably common knowledge. So what's the deal with this release?

Well it's on PC, Steam, has cloud saving, a booster thing that makes the game easier, and achievements that made me play this game much more than I otherwise would have (I'm crazy, ok?). It also has a piece of DRM that i've heard is a real nuisance for some, but I didn't have too much trouble with it. You have to make an account, but once I linked it with my Steam account I never had to worry about it again. The real problem is the instability of their server, which takes down cloud saves during busy hours (during the sale it did, but not after that was done with). It does save locally though, and it updates your cloud save once that gets going again, so it's not really a big deal. Nevertheless, I felt the need to mention all this.

Aside from that, this is FF7 as it was on the PS1 ~15 years ago (I still have a [friend's] copy :o). Everything. The story, gameplay, optional content, and even some glitches (W-Item) carry over to this version.

That's really all I need to say, I think. Chances are you already know if you like this game or not. And if you never played it... well, you can if you want to. I had a decent time, but people tend to love or hate this game. Less because of what it is and more because of what it did: became a standard" for JRPG's that has more or less remained the same ever since
recommended: i'll stop now. Buy if it interests you. You get what you expect: an aged PS1 classic that plays competently on the PC and has a few nice little additions."

reviewText:
This is now the definitive version of the game now that they added PSX music. The translation and graphics are superior to the PSX version and it's most likely going to be cheaper than actually purchasing a physical copy.

As for the game itself, the flaws are all still there and have become as glaring as ever with its age. The story still is as nonsensical as ever, the super deformed characters still look ugly, and the materia system actually destroys the traditional RPG formula for balance and makes each character essentially blank canvases outside of their base stats and limit breaks. That can be fun at first glance but it becomes very bland when every character essentially operates the same way and the end game becomes so single-minded. It's also a turn based/random encounter affair so if those kind of games get on your nerves you should avoid this at all costs. Lastly, the characters are your standard JRPG affair (although at the time, these archetypes in video games weren't common in North America) and most don't really evolve past their initial character development, especially outside of the party.

The good?
-The materia system is fun, flexible, and broken. I can't say I agree with it on a balancing or variety level but on the surface it's fun and gratifying.
-The story ends up being paced pretty well throughout the entire journey which doesn't happen very often with JRPGs.
-Random encounters are paced very well for a JRPG and I didn't find myself ripping my hair out until the final dungeon (two battles every screen with a mastered Enemy Away? Nah).
-There are many side-quests that feel naturally implemented into the world and I enjoyed most of them aside from Chocobo breeding which was nothing but tedious.
-The pre-rendered backgrounds are also usually pleasing to the eye (then again, they're a stark contrast to the awful character models that populate them).
-The music and sound effects are great and overall the presentation has a charm to it that most JRPGs don't.

My personal outlook on the game may have soured a bit over time but the core of the game holds up fairly well to this day despite some obvious flaws. I rate it overall a very strong 7. A worthwhile experience that I think gamers insterested in the history of the medium should attempt to tackle, especially those who are familiar with Japanese RPGs.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VII is universally recognized as the best installment of the series, and maybe one of the best RPG ever. I played the original, on the PS1, all the way through at least four or five times. FF7 was the only game I liked enough to get me to shell out the extra 20 bucks for the guide, just so I could find and/or beat every little side quest or hidden area. It absorbed many countless hours of my youth.

Not to long ago, I found FF7 on Steam and quickly bought it for second time. Now I never did find my old guide (not that you need it with the internet), but I played Final Fantasy VII once again and loved every minute of it. I was reminded of it’s great story and characters, awesome weapons with unique leveling up, the way powers can be mixed together, and the great interface for both battle and world map. I enjoy that you can spend hours racing giant birds around for an awesome hidden item or fighting through a tough dungeon for a unique weapon. But the game doesn’t make you, very little of the required gameplay is grinding. This game does not require continuous, fast button mashing. So if you like to take frequent, short breaks from the game controller to enhance your video gaming experience, Final Fantasy VII is great for that.

After completing this game once again, even though it took a bit longer because of that pesky thing known as a job, I still find it to be my favorite game ever. It has everything that made it great on the PS1, but the PC version is much smoother because of the updated hardware. If are a fan of the original, have played others in the series, or just enjoy RPGs or good games, it will be more than worth it to buy FF7, a great game all around.

reviewText:
Release Date: September 3rd 1997.
Console: Playstation 1.
Ported to PC on June 24th of 1998.

This game revolutionized the way the Roleplaying Games would be and graphics that came as a shock to most people who played RPG's. A stunning storyline and perfect battle system, this game has the most sold copies in the PLANET, a WHOPPING 10 MILLION Copies.

Now ported to Steam, this game is actually MODDABLE. Meaning you can change the overworld graphics, change the Music, everything except storyline. This is one of the very best RPG's that exist. If you don't have this game, You aren't a gamer.

GET IT.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Excellent story.
- Interesting characters.
- Amazing soundtrack (unlike FF8 the music has not been ruined for the Steam version).
- Cutscenes look amazing and the in-battle graphics are very good for the time and are still bearable today.
- Exploration and chocobo breeding is rewarded well.
- Materia system allows for easy change of characters' magic and experimentation.
- The localisation has been mostly fixed.
- Fun in-battle gameplay.
- Grinding is pretty much never necessary for the main storyline.

Cons:
- Out-of-battle character models are terrible.
- Materia system is a bit too simplistic.
- The overall game is far too easy (except for the optional bosses).
- The parts of the game where the pace is slowed down last for too long.

Overall score: 8.5 / 10

reviewText:
Okay, to write a review of Final Fantasy 7 is not a simple task, believe me it's not. Now you've probably heard this before from dozens of people, whether it be your friends, gaming magazines, internet or basically any other form of communication; written or spoken, Final Fantasy 7 is one of the best games of all time, and though now it may seem like an overrated, outdated RPG nearly 17 years later, it deserves the title.

I only beat this game once, and have dived back into it thanks to this updated re-release on Steam. Visually, it's eye-candy to me. Though current-day gamers might turn thier heads, this game looks awesome and if it weren't for the PlayStation's graphical limits, i would say that this is the way the developers originally invisioned the game back in 1997, fluent animations, sharper character models, and just overall better looking port.

The Story is something else, The story of Final Fantasy 7 is not a forgettable one. You begin as part of an eco-terrorist group who is hell-bent on destroying the world's biggest power company for killing the planet, hours into the game later you find yourself on a mission to save a world that is doomed to complete annihilation at the hands of a super-soldier who is taking back the planet". (i hate to give away to much spoilers.)

As for the gameplay it is your typical
recommended: turn-based JRPG. for a series who practically invented the genre
hoursPlayed: this game doesn't stray to far away from it's predecessors in terms of the battle system and means of progression
voteText: hell if you're having trouble understanding how to play

reviewText:
*Note: I Had Not Played This Until About A Month Ago, So These Are My First Impressions Of My First Playthrough.

I Absolutly LOVE This Game, I'd Never Played It Before And In The Matter Of A Month I Became Obsessed And Love It! This Game Can Certainly Be Called One Of The Best Games Of All Time, Being That It Has An Amazing Story, Loveable Characters And A Truely Customizable Way To Play Being That Materia Can Be Used On Any Character And It Can Be Of Any Kind (Ex. Cloud, An Offensive Magic User May Have Some Healing Magic). I Also Love The Way The Cutscenes Work, And How It Has Grapics Similar To The Original PS Version Of The Game. Also Things Like The Side-Bosses Ultima WEAPON, Ruby WEAPON, And Emeral WEAPON Make The Game All The Better Being That It Doesnt Make All The Fights Completely Story Related And That You Can Fight These Side-Bosses At Anytime After Meeting Certain Requirements. I Also Am Very Fond Of The Combat System, Which Is Very Much Like Every Other FF Combat System But It Is Still Amazing And The Feature Of Limit Breaks Blows Other RPG's Out Of The Water! It Also Has A Fairly Decent Amount Of Hours You Have To Put In To Get To Sephiroth's Final Fight. Another Thing I Enjoyed Was Having Some Sidequests To Get Quest Items That Really Help In The End Of The Game, Like Tier 4/Extreme Limit Breaks. It Is Also Very Story Rich Making It Something To Definitly Buy.

My Overall Rating For This Game Would No Doubt Be A 10/10, Because It Has A Great Story, Nice Combat That All FF Games Have, Some Fun Sidequests, Takes A While To Complete (Took Me About 40-50 Hours+ To Complete), And Has Amazing Characters Who Even Have Their Own Little Backstories

reviewText:
Despite my coming to the party 18 years late, Final Fantasy VII was one of my favourite games I played in 2015. Expecting greatness when I went in, I tried my best not to get immersed in it thinking it was good because of all the universal praise it gets; it didn't take long for me to realize I didn't have to, because I could see it for myself.

Before I get to the actual meat and potatoes part of this review, looking at the negative reviews, I see a lot of criticism towards Square Enix about having to make a Squenix account in order to play, which is understandable in 2016 with a lot of people being very protective of their information (seeing as some personal information is mandatory to sign up, if I remember correctly). If you're so worried about this, I recommend you read more about it, because if I'm going to be honest, I'm not familiar with what Square Enix can and can't do with what you give them. If you don't want to support Squenix, I don't want to support piracy, but you should put some thought into it.

I'm also going to make it clear that this is the only Final Fantasy game I've ever played; if you've played other games in the series and are looking for a comparison, this guide is likely not for you.




Final Fantasy VII is thought of universally as one of the best RPGs, or even one of the best video games of all time, and while I'm not sure how much I agree with that, I can definitely stand by the claim that the majority of its praise is well deserved.

The characters are all memorable, creative and unique, and are personal enough to make you care about what happens to them and the world around them. The dialogue between them is excellent, and portrays a great level of personality and emotion, and creates great relationships such as the passive-aggressive friendship between Cloud and Barret, and how Yuffie is seen as the immature Materia loving ninja girl always looking for a fight.

The 85-song soundtrack is incredible, with songs that portray emotion and songs that portray anger, or a sense of adventure, or a feeling of despair, anxiousness, being back in your hometown, any song you'd expect in a dramatic RPG, just done better, and made to work on PlayStation 1 hardware, no less (although I don't really know how all that works). And if you enjoy it as much as I do, I recommend you listen to the official Final Fantasy VII - Piano Collections album (Cinco de Chocobo and Tifa's Theme are my favourites).

The graphics, in all honesty, have NOT aged well; the pixelated battle backgrounds, while revolutionary for their time and still a nice touch today are not amazing visually, but in terms of the blocky and polygonal model appearances and the repetitive shrug, anger and disappointment animations used for nearly every character with a humanoid build, they're charming in a sense, in the same way people look at the 30+ year old Super Mario Bros. Mario sprite. And if the PS1 style graphics bother you that much, there are indeed graphical mods out there (although I couldn't tell you much about them, I've never used any).

Despite being a typical RPG, the gameplay is fresh and exciting, even going into it today. The Materia system, in which you attach magic-based attacks, monster summons, or bonuses like HP Plus or Magic Plus makes the entire magic system more interesting and complex, and the unique 'ATB' battle system allows for real-time RPG combat as opposed to turn-based (although this can be configured in the game's settings; if this is your first Final Fantasy game you might want to read about ATB because it can be confusing at first; I actually jumped into this game expecting turn-based and was surprised when the enemy would attack me in the middle of a menu. If this is not for you, look into the options menu.) Limit breaks keep the battles interesting and can quickly turn the tide of a losing battle, used by filling the Limit Gauge which fills the more damage you take (but make note this is far from a crutch to help a bad player.)

And the last thing I'm going to mention, but far from the least important, is the story; while complicated and sometimes unnecessarily complex, the story of Final Fantasy VII is a long roller-coaster of surprise and drama, involving AVALANCHE's quest to stop Shinra Headquarters, Sephiroth's rampage and plot to kill the world, black materia, lifestream, Mako energy, among many other subjects.

Branching storylines include Cloud's conflict with his real self, Barret's disappointment in himself for failing to protect his hometown, and many other unique and dramatic storylines within the game. It's honestly a lot to keep track of and remember, and even harder to write about, but the point I'm making is that the story is never lacking in any places and you never feel as if what you're doing has no important outcome or consequence; I was thoroughly entertained without the game, which I honestly didn't expect; I expected to play it continously every day for maybe an hour, but I would spend days playing in 6-hour periods, which is something I rarely do for any game I enjoy, just to see what would end up happening because of the actions I took in the past.

In terms of things I wasn't pleased with or I feel could have been done better, I feel like I need to make note that the story is pretty hard to follow at times, and it can be hard to lose track of what you're doing and why you're doing it, but this might just be a personal thing.

On the topic of cons, this game has a lot of unnecessary minigames, and I mean a LOT of them. What makes this worse is that this port of Final Fantasy VII, while completely functional and complete with Cloud saving (heh), if you're playing on a keyboard, the game is not set to recognize what button you have to what input, so if you're being instructed to press a key, it will say [CANCEL] for example instead of [X]. This goes the same way no matter what kind of controller you're using; a friend of mine played it on a GameCube controller.

Back on the topic of minigames, I'm having Vietnam flashbacks remembering a marching minigame in which you have to press the keys it asks for (which you might not be familiar with because it doesn't tell you which letter on the keyboard), and other similar minigames in this vein. There's an unnecessary amount that honestly could just be changed into a cutscene, such as a slap-fight between Tifa and the female Turk (although this one was actually kinda funny), a squat battle (you heard me), pushing barrels onto Shinra soldiers who are chasing Aeris (or Aerith ♥♥♥♥ you), among others. Some of them are fun for the most part, but generally speaking I feel like they're just wasting my time, but I appreciate the effort to give the user some control.

But despite the game's problems, I would recommend Final Fantasy VII to anybody in a heartbeat. TL;DR, the characters are unique and personal, the music sounds spectaular and works great with the game, the story makes you care and keeps you involved, and the gameplay is nothing you've seen before. I would recommend this for full price.

reviewText: With much trepidation I decided to replay this for the first time in 16 years. I thought this game might suffer viciously with time, dreading that all my very fond memories of this game were about to be destroyed. Would that amazing story hold up? Would I get immersed again? Apart from the graphics (you could have done a little prettying up, SE!) the game is still brilliant. It's lost nothing with time, and everything is as I remembered and loved. Warm fuzzy feels included.\n\nIf you haven't played this game you should. This is what a game with a proper, involved and well told story is like. This is what gaming used to be. If you have played it but are nervous about all your good memories of this game being annihilated, stop being a ♥♥♥♥♥ and play it. It won't break your memories. Embrace the nostalgia.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy 7 is considered by many to be the best Final Fantasy game to ever exist and is close to many people's hearts. While not being my favorite of the series it is certainly up there. If you want to play a classic final fantasy game this is for you.

While being a port this game functions quite well on the PC and can even be played quite easily without a controller which is a major plus for those who do not have one. Adding achievements was a nice touch as well.

There is little to say about this game that has not been said, it's a solid game and if you like RPGs you should definitely grab it.
