reviewText:
FF7 is a monolith of my childhood. How do you review a game with so much hype and pomp and fanatical emotion? It's easier than I thought it would be, given that I can play it again. It's just like I remember. FF7 is like putting on a warm sweater and drinking hot cider. It's a comfort-game. Let me explain.


FF7 came out when I was 11. I did not get to play it until I was 12. Everyone told me how great it was--and how it was introducing western audiences to the Japanese RPG world by storm. So when I got a used Playstation, I got the game.

I did not know it at the time, but this FF game was unlike the six that preceeded it in terms of setting and magic system. So I had no bias to base my analysis off of. All I knew was that the Materia system was great. It was easy to use and learn--and as I got better at the game, I began to think up more complex combinations of Materia and equipment. (Woo, Curse Ring and then Added Effect/Destruct in linked Armor slots) There were literally, thousands of combinations. And that's not even touching Enemy-Skill, Morph and Manipulate.

The Materia system was rock solid. You could completely customize what characters you felt would be best for certain combinations. You weren't constrained by this idea of a Character Class--at least in regards to magic. In terms of weapons, yes, perhaps that was more restricted--but I loved it. Everyone was different--it was perfect. You could create an awesome balance between tanks like Barret and speedsters like Tifa---with characters like Nanaki, Vincent and Yuffie--who were skilled physically and magically.

And of course, you can't have a game without good characters. Despite the foamy mustache that Square has gotten from milking FF7 for everything its got--don't believe what they've done to Cloud. In FF7, he was not the whiny little angst-machine that Square has turned him into. He went through big things in FF7 and he got low--but he came back. He got back up, dusted himself off and kept going. That was the entire point. But Square would have you thinking he spends all his time whining and moping around. Not true. When Advent Children came out, I was quite confused because their Cloud wasn't acting like...well, Cloud.


Aeris is your Mary Sue Last of her Race, Magic MacGuffin Carrier Female White Mage thing. I make a point to get her out of my party ASAP. This is only because I personally don't like her. I hate her snippy attitude, her selfishness and her blatant disregard of everyone around her--except for Cloud. She is the most irritating character. However---that is just my personal opinion (besides, the game did me a solid and I forgave them at, you know, That Part). As a character--Aeris moves the plot along and she IS a helluva powerful White Mage/Magic User. When I have to have her with me, I always put Cover on her and Fury---so whenever she takes a hit for someone, it ramps up her Limit Break bar and then she busts out the Holy magic.


Tifa kind of lists back and forth between annoying and cool. She's the fistfighter/monk character and between her and Aeris, I'll take Tifa. She can deal some real damage (Powersoul + Curse Ring = Constant 4x damage infliction) and she has a real connection with Cloud. Whereas with Aeris--her thing with Cloud feels very shallow---Tifa actually feels very natural with Cloud. She cares about him, deeply. And when you learn about him--he cares about her.

Barret is your angry tank/heavy gunner. I would say he's probably the least characterized (except for Cait Sith) but he's a good long range strong arm.

Nanaki, I really like too---he's very calm, collected and thoughtful. He's very reasonable, not one o pin blame like Barrett does sometimes.

Cid Highwind is my favorite--tough-talking roughneck chainsmoking pilot. He gets jipped a lot for some reason. But he's the Reluctant Leader. He can lead, he's fine with leading---but he can also follow. He's not insecure like Barrett and if he needs to step up, he does. And his crew respects him for it. He's got balls--but he's not a jerk. Cid curses and is kind of rough and tumble---but when he makes that one short speech about how their planet is wandering small and lonely in the universe, it shows a little more in there.

Yuffie is my favorite of the ladies. Okay, yes, she'll steal your stuff---but she has so much personality (and she doesn't fawn over Cloud). She's straight-forward, to the point, hilariously awful sometimes. And once you get her leveled up--she is a straight up badass. One of my favorite things to do when Cid is the leader---is put her, Vincent and Cid together to go on the Train Mission. OMG, funny. She is so hilarious. She's like a Chaotic Neutral---might save your life, might steal your car. And I love that about her. They seem to have gotten away from her character type later--which I think is a real shame. (Also, I ship Yuffie and Reno forever.)


And then, of course, the Big Bad. THE Big Bad. Sephiroth. A psychotic momma's boy, who will kil you, your dog, your dog's puppies, your kitchen table and then burn your house down. He literally does not give a crap about anyone or anything--but gaining power and reclaiming Gaia for Jenova. His brutality is brought home--and made personal. Cloud's backstory with Tifa in Nibelheim, Zack and then finally culminating with Aeris in the Forgotten City. His menace, his power--its legendary. You hear about Sephiroth at the very beginning of the game. You don't even see him until several hours later into gameplay. And even then--its in Cloud's flashback. The way Sephiroth is presented is masterful. They talked it up, told you how strong and crazy-evil he was, built and built and built on it--until you finally get to see him for yourself and for once, he's everything that you've heard.


This was what made it for me. Excellent pacing, a good blend of character types so that you can customize your party how you wanted (I'd rather not like a character, than be indifferent to the characters; FF8's characters were so bland--I hated it), an intuitive and creative magic and battle system, tons of sidequests, hours and hours of things to do. To just explore the World Map.

I feel like this was Square at its very best. When they wrote a complex but compelling story, a game where--each time I play, I find something I didn't know was there. I only recently discovered the Curse Ring in Mideel--or if you visit Johnny's parents in Sector 7 before its destroyed, his father talks about Nibelheim (I was like: WHOA!) and countless other small details that enrich the gameplay. Its what keeps me coming back over and over again. I've played this game countless times--and each time, I enjoy it.

Yeah, the graphics are old. It doesn't matter--its the story, the mechanics, the characters. Advent Children had beautiful graphics, beautiful. But its story was completely lame, the plot was ridiculously stupid--it was all just fanservice. So I dont even bother with all the other stuff that Square came out with to milk the FF7 cow.

I'd say they should just remake FF7---but I'm afraid they'd start messing around and changing things. Don't trust 'em. Haha.


This is one game--where it lived up to its hype. It exceeded my expectations. I saw FF7 when it came out on EA's website and I about had a heart attack. I bought instantly, that very night, that minute. And then about a week later, it came out on Steam. And I got another copy on Steam--just so that I'd always have it. Look passed the graphics, immerse yourself in the story and the dynamic characters. It's worth it. I would have paid $30 for a copy of this game--and they're selling it for $12. Worth every penny.

reviewText: With much trepidation I decided to replay this for the first time in 16 years. I thought this game might suffer viciously with time, dreading that all my very fond memories of this game were about to be destroyed. Would that amazing story hold up? Would I get immersed again? Apart from the graphics (you could have done a little prettying up, SE!) the game is still brilliant. It's lost nothing with time, and everything is as I remembered and loved. Warm fuzzy feels included.\n\nIf you haven't played this game you should. This is what a game with a proper, involved and well told story is like. This is what gaming used to be. If you have played it but are nervous about all your good memories of this game being annihilated, stop being a ♥♥♥♥♥ and play it. It won't break your memories. Embrace the nostalgia.

reviewText:
Keep in mind, this is a very short review. I am going to give an opinion of the game but I wont go into depth becuase I am sure I would end up leaving something out even if I sat here for 7 hours trying to write the review, so here it is:

This game is one of the best games I have ever played, if not the absolute best. Nostalgia is not a factor here what so ever as I first played this game last year after buying it during the holiday sale. This game is NOT overhyped by any means, don't let someone's opinion of that prevent you from playing this game. It was amazing when it first released and it is amazing now.

The music is perfect and fits every situation in the game while sounding great.

The story is better than almost any I have ever experienced in a work of fiction, including novels and movies.

The graphics are simple, but because they are stylized I like the way the game looks anyway, simple does not always equal bad.

If you love turn-based gameplay, the you will love this game. If you don't like turn-based gameplay, you might warm up to it after this game. Having three chracters with an Active Time" system makes the battles fast paced and forces you to think quickly.

The materia system will you an extreme amount of freedom when playing
date: allowing you to have characters act similarly to any Final Fantasy class type. Or you could just make them unique
recommended: they don't have to mirror any class if you want them too. Combos of many different types are possible with the materia system as well.\n\nThe characters in this game are some of the most well done
hoursPlayed: multi-dimetional characters I have ever seen in a work of fiction. Both the chracters and story end up being so complex (without being messy) that to this day people still have heated debates on them. This game also has a habit of making unforgettable moments for the player
voteText: but for obvious reason I wont state examples.\n\nThere is so much more to this game
helpfulPercent: but as I said before
votesHelpful: I am not going to make this a long review.\nThis game is a perfect 10 out of 10
votesTotal: you really should play it.\n\nAlso Cloud Strife
votesFunny: the main character of this game
commentsCount: is now going to be in Super Smash Brothers 4. That's pretty cool."

reviewText: There's really not much I can say about Final Fantasy 7 that hasn't already been said. It was a revolutionary game and it changed the face of RPGs forever. Some say it was for the best, others disagree.\n\nIn any case you've likely heard all the JRPG stereotypes, the random battles, and the menu based combat. The storyline is extremely character driven, and it's one of the highlights of the entire experience. That's not counting the large world you explore, the sidequests and all the optional content. Much of which most players don't know about until they read a wiki. Final Fantasy 7 is a game about replayability and choices, and one that anyone can enjoy.

Great story? Check

Open world RPG? Yes my dear, check.

reviewText:
To be upfront, I have not yet finished this game, nor have I played through it in the past.  That said, I feel I've gained enough of a feel for the game to write a useful review.  I'll update this once I'm done...

Quick Review:
Dated, yet lovable graphics.  Good MIDI soundtrack.  Enchanting story with winsome characters.  Fun battles with varied opponents.  Customizable fighting style to fit many approaches...
A little slow paced for the impatient people, but decidedly worth the time...
I recommend.

Graphics:
Not very impressive for the times.  I personally have some knowledge of how games are made, so I can at least partly appreciate how fantastic this must've looked on release.  It was one of the pioneer games that showed the incredible potential of what games could be.  That potential (graphically) is being realized today, so hats off to Square Enix for boldly helping kick things off for us...
However, it's not really all that great by today's standards.  The character models are so low-poly, it's near laughable.  The backgrounds are very nice compositions, but so heavily pixellated that it's sometimes difficult to see what's what.
The camera angles are creative and dramatic, and the special effects are varied and entertaining, but again, not even close to the same level as today's games.
Overall, it was hard for me to get past the graphics at first.  But as the game progressed, they were varied enough and creative enough to satisfy my experience.  Anyway, they get overshadowed by the rest of the game's magnificence...

Story:
Absolutely beautiful.  I haven't even gotten halfway through this game, and i'm already so invested with the story that I'm analyzing it and pondering it during the times I'm not playing.  Sure, there's a smidgen of predictability to it.  Sure, there's times where the cheezy" is so intense you can taste it.  But the dialog is so brilliantly written
hoursPlayed: that it resonates with the player and draws them in.  You are fed a steady diet of backstory

reviewText:
AUDIO: Excellent                                              AESTHETIC: Classic
MEMORABILITY: Unforgettable                       WORTH: Discounted

PROS: Music has been changed back from MIDI form. Cloud-saving is kind of nice I suppose, since the game is so long (It can also be disabled.) Mistranslations and errors have been fixed. The game itself flows smoothly and is not prone to eye-sore jittering. I have not run into any crashing. FF7 itself is a great part of RPG history and worth a try.

CONS: Logging in with Square is irritating and leads to issues if you aren't connected via internet. I'm not sure that level of invasiveness in the DRM is worth what benefits it gives you. The monster designs in this one are absolutely laughable, to the point of embarrassment.

OVERALL: Solid port that has fixed issues both in the original PC and PSX versions.

SCORE: 9/10

reviewText:
This game changed my life as a child, as a 5 or 6 year old watching my dad play through and trying to follow him on my own save file,  this was probably the first *real* game I ever played.  This game and Zelda: Ocarina of Time define my childhood and set me on the path of gaming for the rest of my life.
The storyline is deep and rich and complex but still makes perfect sense, which is more than can be said about later entries in the series (FF13 I'm looking at you)
The graphics might be obviously dated but this game has established itself as an all time classic.  You will not regret purchasing this game if you didn't get the chance to play it on the PSX.  I've personally completed this game maybe 20 or 30 times.  And still play it now almost 20 years later at least once a year.

Graphics (for their time) 8/10
Game play:  9/10
Storyline:  10/10
The grind: 8/10  you level up well with the story but not enough to make the game too easy.

The materia system is by far my favorite magic system in any FF title, it's almost as much fun trying to max out each one as it is playing the rest of the game.  Think getting a lv100 pokemon but even better.

over all, and considering this game as stood up to the test of time for TWENTY YEARS,  I'd rate it 10/10 and not ironically or satirically.  I really mean it, this game is so god damn powerful and if you're younger it'll change your life playing it for the first time.

Enjoy

reviewText: THIS GAME IS DRM!!!!!! DO NOT BUY!!!!!! If you do not have an internet connection you will NOT be able to play this game!!! I am a little late on this myself but ALL of Square Enix's games are now becoming DRM. I have also DL some of the SNES classics on my iphone only to find out that when I am on a plane or on a road trip in the middle of nowhere I cannot play ANY of them due to a lack of internet. My experiance a a gamer and the concept of consumer goodwill should be disregarded just so Square can feel safe. The fact that they are DRM is NOT listed anywhere on the Steam store as well as the Google Play and Apple stores. I am a long time FF fan however this is too much for me and I will not be purchesing another Square game (yes, even the FF:7 remake) as long as they continue this practice. reviewText:
This version is apparently based on a 2010 or 2011 PC rerelease that Squenix had a while back with bugs and the like as well as still having rubbish sub-optimal PC MIDI music. Or at least, this version used to. The good news is Squenix has patched the game to have the original Playstation version's music meaning better quality instruments and One Winged Angel with actual lyrics now, so that's one flaw scratched off the list and no more need for music mods unless you want 2014 Triple A level orchestra guff. I haven't run into any serious bugs either.

The big draw of this version is cloud saving (I get the joke, thanks Square) which only works some of the time, and a Booster system that gives you more Gil and buffs your stats so you can just enjoy the story. For casual fans wanting in on FF7's story its pretty neat. For vets like me, eh, its there, its optional, its not hurting anyone, we can play it the real man's way if we like.

Otherwise the game is unchanged from 1998, same gameplay, same story. Unfortunately since this is the later PC port of the game it uses the updated translation in its script, so no more Aeris declaring that This guy are sick" anymore
date: some of the swearing is Q*Berted and various other bits. Yet Cloud still tells you to attack the first boss when its tail is up. Git.\n\nI'd still definitely get this game
recommended: especially for the base price of £9.99
hoursPlayed: if you wanna check out some quality olden day RPG before all the Triple A cinematics

reviewText:
AUDIO: Excellent                                              AESTHETIC: Classic
MEMORABILITY: Unforgettable                       WORTH: Discounted

PROS: Music has been changed back from MIDI form. Cloud-saving is kind of nice I suppose, since the game is so long (It can also be disabled.) Mistranslations and errors have been fixed. The game itself flows smoothly and is not prone to eye-sore jittering. I have not run into any crashing. FF7 itself is a great part of RPG history and worth a try.

CONS: Logging in with Square is irritating and leads to issues if you aren't connected via internet. I'm not sure that level of invasiveness in the DRM is worth what benefits it gives you. The monster designs in this one are absolutely laughable, to the point of embarrassment.

OVERALL: Solid port that has fixed issues both in the original PC and PSX versions.

SCORE: 9/10

reviewText:
First of all,I'd like to say there is no good or bad game really.It all depends on your personal preferences.One may find a certain game fun while the other might not.Anyway,I'm actually a bit half-half on this game when it comes to recommending and I'll tell you why.

-FF7 has a really GREAT storyline to it(that's what I love about Final Fantasy).It's not your typical predictable story.It just pulls you in.PLUS POINTS FOR THAT.

-When it comes to gameplay,it's not your typical hack-n-slash style or fps.It involves characters taking turns to make their moves and you select and action for the character to take for example attack/magic/defend etc etc.(If you don't understand what I'm saying,you can always search for a video on youtube on final fantasy 7 battles).Personally I like this system.It's fun and unique:} In case there are people out there who are worried it may be confusing,don't worry,it's not:)PLUS POINTS!

-Brilliant cutscenes.For a game that has somewhat oldish" looking graphics (no offence it's a fact)
date: it has some pretty neat looking cutscenes.I was amazed when I saw the first few cutscenes(and the later ones afterwards).I really enjoyed watching every one of it.PLUS POINTS AGAIN!\n\n-As you play the main character
recommended: you're not alone.You have friends together on your journey:3 Hurray! So
hoursPlayed: these other characters that join your main character are interesting
voteText:
fascinating and unique.Having their own rich personality as well and their own stories.PLUS POINTS.

Now for the negative part..

For some reason
helpfulPercent: I feel that the amount of damage you can deal is pretty "suckish" even if you level up pretty high.Either that or the enemies are superbly strong.Or it could be both.I say that because from my experience from another Final Fantasy game
votesHelpful: FFX to be exact
votesTotal: I levelled up my characters to a pretty decent level(not all the way to 99) and I could still win and complete the game)Some enemies can just easily land you one-hit kills.ONE-HIT and you're dead.This pretty much means that it's kinda tricky to take down enemies.It can be really frustrating sometimes.I remember when I was stuck near the final stages of the game where I had to beat the enemy boss.He was so difficult to take down even after 30 mins.I've seen several people on youtube who posts videos of their ff7 gameplays on beating this boss and they successfully did it but I realised something.I've seen people who levelled up their characters all the way to lvl 99
votesFunny: acquired special items from side quests

reviewText: This is, without a doubt, one of the best RPGs I've played over the years. It's engaging, it's fun, and the world is so huge, with so much to explore. reviewText:
I don't do many reviews but having this game in my inventory without a review just doesn't feel right.

This is the game.

This is the game to define a genre... That stands among the greatest things to ever be created, not just as a video game but as a work of art. If aliens were to land on our planet and ask for an example of our finest works, I would proudly hand them a piece of pizza, a glass of pumpkin egg nog and this game.

Because of how old this game is, the graphics will turn some people away... But if you're one of the lucky ones to have not picked this game up yet, then look past the pixels and into the heart of what can only be described as a masterpiece.

reviewText:
No sé cuántas veces lo he jugado ya. En PlayStation One, en PSP, en PC (emulando psx) y ahora en Steam también. Os voy a dar una visión bastante sencilla de este juego... ES UN JUEGAZO. Cuando juegas a él, cuando te sumerges en la historia... no puedes parar, quiere seguir descubriendo que cojones está pasando aquí y porque hay tanto hecho polvo de la cabeza en la historia. Vayamos por partes.

Gráficos: Una ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥, no hay por donde cogerlos. La gente no tiene puños, tiene cubos. Muy Minecraft todo. Para 1997 no está mal, pero 18 años después va a ser que cambia la cosa.

Jugabilidad: El sistema de materias ofrece tantísimas posibilidades... yo me he tirado muuuchas horas en total equipando materias en las ranuras, buscando la mejor configuración y combinando todo lo posible. Hay algunas configuraciones que son la hostia.

Historia: Los buenos, los malos, el malomalísimo, los secundarios, los escenarios, los acontecimientos, el nacimiento de las weapons, los que personajes que nos dejan en mitad... TODO tiene su razón y su conexión en LA MEJOR HISTORIA jamás contada en un videojuego... LA MEJOR... JAMÁS...

Jugadlo, no os arrepentiréis, si le hacéis un pequeño hueco en vuestro corazón os recompensaré con un viaje increíble que ningún otro Final Fantasy (ni cualquier videojuego en particular) conseguirá.

reviewText: “Let’s mosey!”\n\nI effectively ruined my original '97 hardcopy dics with how often I've replayed and burned through this game. The entire VII compilation (from Before Crisis to Advent Children) is something I hold very near and dear to my heart. VII isn't everyone's favorite Final Fantasy installation, saying it doesn't live up to it's hype, but I honestly think you can't overstate how EPIC this game is. It rightfully holds its place on the pedestal of one of the greats in the series--and in gaming entirely. Classic FF battle mechanics with the addition of a GREAT materia system makes necessary leveling up enjoyable. Graphics are most certainly dated, but to be honest, it’s so easy to look past playing with blocks of colored polygons for characters on maps. That’s how good it is. An engrossing story; good gameplay; a memorable, iconic soundtrack; and the most beautiful characterization and character development (especially if you follow the ragtag team throughout the compilation) that isn’t selective to a choice few party members—and you’ve got yourself a game that still remains strong after nearly 20 years.
